   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Vietnam</h1>

     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

       Country in Southeast Asia
      </div>

      <table role="presentation" class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <td class="mbox-image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/26px-Chu_nom.svg.png" decoding="async" width="26" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/39px-Chu_nom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/52px-Chu_nom.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="144" data-file-height="219"></td> 
         <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> text.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:Multilingual_support_(East_Asian)" title="Help:Multilingual support (East Asian)">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a> instead of <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_n%C3%B4m" class="mw-redirect" title="Chữ nôm">chữ nôm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_H%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Chữ Hán">chữ Hán</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_alphabet" title="Vietnamese alphabet">chữ quốc ngữ</a>.</td>
        </tr> 
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Vietnam</b> (also written as <b>Viet Nam</b>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Việt Nam</i>, <small></small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Vietnamese" title="Help:IPA/Vietnamese">[vîət nāːm]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vietnam.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Vietnam.ogg" class="internal" title="Vietnam.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Socialist Republic of Vietnam</b><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[10]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Cộng hòa Xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam</i>), is a country in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> and the easternmost country on the <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Southeast_Asia" title="Mainland Southeast Asia">Indochinese Peninsula</a>. With an estimated 98.7&nbsp;million inhabitants as of 2020, it is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">16th most populous country in the world</a>. Vietnam shares its land borders with <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to the north, and <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> to the west. It shares its maritime borders with <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Thailand" title="Gulf of Thailand">Gulf of Thailand</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> through the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[n 5]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Capital_city" title="Capital city">capital city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, and its most populous city is <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>. </p>
      <p>Archaeological excavations indicate that Vietnam was inhabited as early as the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> age. The ancient Vietnamese nation, which was centered on the <a href="/wiki/Hong_River" title="Hong River">Red River valley</a> and nearby coastal areas, was annexed by the <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> in the 2nd century BC, which subsequently made Vietnam a division of Imperial China for over a millennium. The first independent <a href="/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_monarchs" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Vietnamese monarchs">monarchy</a> emerged in the 10th century AD. This paved the way for successive <a href="/wiki/List_of_monarchs_of_Vietnam" title="List of monarchs of Vietnam">imperial dynasties</a> as the nation <a href="/wiki/Nam_ti%E1%BA%BFn" title="Nam tiến">expanded southward</a> until the Indochina Peninsula was <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">colonised by the French</a> in the late 19th century. Modern Vietnam was born upon the <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Independence_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Proclamation of Independence of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Proclamation of Independence</a> from France in 1945. Following Vietnamese victory against the French in the <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a>, which ended in 1954, the nation was divided into two rival states: communist <a href="/wiki/North_Vietnam" title="North Vietnam">North</a> and anti-communist <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South</a>. Conflicts intensified in the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, which saw <a href="/wiki/Role_of_the_United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Role of the United States in the Vietnam War">extensive US intervention</a> in support of South Vietnam and ended with <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">North Vietnamese victory</a> in 1975. </p>
      <p>After North and South Vietnam were reunified as a <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist state</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist</a> government in 1976, the country became economically and politically isolated until 1986, when the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party</a> initiated a series of <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">economic and political reforms</a> that facilitated Vietnamese integration into world politics and the global economy. As a result of the successful reforms, Vietnam has enjoyed a high GDP growth rate, consistently ranked among the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest-growing countries in the world</a>. It nevertheless faces challenges including <a href="/wiki/Corruption" title="Corruption">corruption</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pollution" title="Pollution">pollution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a>, inadequate social welfare and a <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Vietnam" title="Human rights in Vietnam">poor human rights record</a>, including increasing persecution of religious groups and human rights advocates and intensifying restrictions on civil liberties.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[12]</a></sup> By 2010, Vietnam had established <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Vietnam" title="Foreign relations of Vietnam">diplomatic relations</a> with 178 countries. It is a member of such international organisations as the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN), the <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a> (ASEAN), the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> (APEC) forum, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO). </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">
       <input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Etymology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Vietnam" title="Names of Vietnam">Names of Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The name <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text">Việt Nam</i> (<small>Vietnamese pronunciation:&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Vietnamese" title="Help:IPA/Vietnamese">[viə̀t naːm]</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_H%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Chữ Hán">chữ Hán</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r867716940">.mw-parser-output .vi-nom{font-family:"Han-Nom Gothic","Nom Na Tong","Han-Nom Ming","Han-Nom Minh","HAN NOM A","HAN NOM B","Han-Nom Kai","Sun-ExtA","Sun-ExtB","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-UNI-H","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-ExtB","HanaMinA","HanaMinB","HanaMin","MingLiU","MingLiU-ExtB","MingLiU HKSCS","MingLiU HKSCS-ExtB","SimSun","SimSun-ExtB","FZKaiT-Extended","FZKaiT-Extended(SIP)",sans-serif}.mw-parser-output .vi-nom .ext{font-family:"Han-Nom Gothic","Han-Nom Ming","Han-Nom Minh","BabelStone Han","Sun-ExtB","MingLiU HKSCS-ExtB","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-ExtB","HanaMinB","Han-Nom Kai",sans-serif}</style><span lang="vi-Hani" title="Vietnamese-language text"><span class="vi-nom"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B6%8A%E5%8D%97" class="extiw" title="wikt:越南">越南</a></span></span>) is a variation of <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text"><a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nam Việt</a></i> (
       <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r867716940"><span lang="vi-Hani" title="Vietnamese-language text"><span class="vi-nom"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8D%97%E8%B6%8A" class="extiw" title="wikt:南越">南越</a></span></span>; literally "Southern <i>Việt</i>"), a name that can be traced back to the <a href="/wiki/Tri%E1%BB%87u_dynasty" title="Triệu dynasty">Triệu dynasty</a> of the 2nd century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200238_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200238-18">[13]</a></sup> The word <i>Việt</i> originated as a shortened form of <a href="/wiki/Baiyue" title="Baiyue">Bách Việt</a> (
       <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r867716940"><span lang="vi-Hani" title="Vietnamese-language text"><span class="vi-nom"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BE%E8%B6%8A" class="extiw" title="wikt:百越">百越</a></span></span>), the name of a group of people then living in southern China and Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYue_Hashimoto19721_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYue_Hashimoto19721-19">[14]</a></sup> The form <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text">Việt Nam</i> (
       <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r867716940"><span lang="vi-Hani" title="Vietnamese-language text"><span class="vi-nom"><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B6%8A%E5%8D%97" class="extiw" title="wikt:越南">越南</a></span></span>) is first recorded in the 16th-century oracular poem <i><a href="/wiki/S%E1%BA%A5m_Tr%E1%BA%A1ng_Tr%C3%ACnh" class="mw-redirect" title="Sấm Trạng Trình">Sấm Trạng Trình</a></i>. The name has also been found on 12 <a href="/wiki/Stele" title="Stele">steles</a> carved in the 16th and 17th centuries, including one at Bao Lam Pagoda in <a href="/wiki/Haiphong" title="Haiphong">Hải Phòng</a> that dates to 1558.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhan1976510_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhan1976510-20">[15]</a></sup> In 1802, <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Ph%C3%BAc_%C3%81nh" class="mw-redirect" title="Nguyễn Phúc Ánh">Nguyễn Phúc Ánh</a> (who later became Emperor Gia Long) established the <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguyễn dynasty">Nguyễn dynasty</a>. In the second year of his rule, he asked the <a href="/wiki/Jiaqing_Emperor" title="Jiaqing Emperor">Jiaqing Emperor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a> to confer on him the title 'King of Nam Việt / Nanyue' (<span lang="zh" title="Chinese-language text">南越</span> in Chinese character) after seizing power in Annam. The Emperor refused since the name was related to <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Tuo" title="Zhao Tuo">Zhao Tuo</a>'s Nanyue, which included the regions of <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a> in southern China. The Qing Emperor, therefore, decided to call the area "Việt Nam" instead.<sup id="cite_ref-etymology_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-22">[n 6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932-23">[17]</a></sup> Between 1804 and 1813, the name Vietnam was used officially by Emperor Gia Long.<sup id="cite_ref-etymology_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-22">[n 6]</a></sup> It was revived in the early 20th century in <a href="/wiki/Phan_B%E1%BB%99i_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Phan Bội Châu">Phan Bội Châu</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Loss_of_Vietnam" title="History of the Loss of Vietnam">History of the Loss of Vietnam</a></i>, and later by the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Nam_Qu%E1%BB%91c_D%C3%A2n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3ng" title="Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng">Vietnamese Nationalist Party</a> (VNQDĐ).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996117_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996117-24">[18]</a></sup> The country was usually called Annam until 1945, when the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">imperial government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Huế">Huế</a> adopted <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text">Việt Nam</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996126_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996126-25">[19]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Vietnam" title="History of Vietnam">History of Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Prehistory">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of a Đông Sơn bronze drum" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/220px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="178" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/330px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/440px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1680" data-file-height="1360"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_drums" class="mw-redirect" title="Đông Sơn drums">Đông Sơn</a> bronze drum, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 800 BC</span>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Archaeological excavations have revealed the existence of humans in what is now Vietnam as early as the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> age. <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> fossils dating to around 500,000 BC have been found in caves in <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1ng_S%C6%A1n_Province" title="Lạng Sơn Province">Lạng Sơn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ngh%E1%BB%87_An_Province" title="Nghệ An Province">Nghệ An</a> provinces in northern Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcKinney2009_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcKinney2009-26">[20]</a></sup> The oldest <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" class="mw-redirect" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> fossils from mainland Southeast Asia are of <a href="/wiki/Middle_Pleistocene" class="mw-redirect" title="Middle Pleistocene">Middle Pleistocene</a> provenance, and include isolated tooth fragments from Tham Om and Hang Hum.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAkazawaAokiKimura1992321_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAkazawaAokiKimura1992321-27">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERabett2012109_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERabett2012109-28">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDennellPorr201441_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDennellPorr201441-29">[23]</a></sup> Teeth attributed to <i>Homo sapiens</i> from the <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a> have been found at Dong Can,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraYonedaYukioOxenham200812_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraYonedaYukioOxenham200812-30">[24]</a></sup> and from the Early <a href="/wiki/Holocene" title="Holocene">Holocene</a> at Mai Da Dieu,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraLan_CuongKim_ThuyAnezaki2001_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraLan_CuongKim_ThuyAnezaki2001-31">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxenhamTayles200636_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxenhamTayles200636-32">[26]</a></sup> Lang Gao<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEanon.198516_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEanon.198516-33">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarlströmKällén200283_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarlströmKällén200283-34">[28]</a></sup> and Lang Cuom.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxenhamBuckley2015329_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxenhamBuckley2015329-35">[29]</a></sup> By about 1,000 BC, the development of wet-<a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> cultivation in the <a href="/wiki/Ma_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Ma River">Ma River</a> and <a href="/wiki/Red_River_(Asia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Red River (Asia)">Red River</a> floodplains led to the flourishing of <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Đông Sơn culture">Đông Sơn culture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigham1984_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigham1984-36">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731-37">[31]</a></sup> notable for its <a href="/wiki/Bronze" title="Bronze">bronze</a> casting used to make elaborate bronze <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_drums" class="mw-redirect" title="Đông Sơn drums">Đông Sơn drums</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEde_LaetHerrmann1996408_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEde_LaetHerrmann1996408-38">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalò200951_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalò200951-39">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan201731_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan201731-40">[34]</a></sup> At this point, the early Vietnamese kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Lang" class="mw-redirect" title="Văn Lang">Văn Lang</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_L%E1%BA%A1c" title="Âu Lạc">Âu Lạc</a> appeared, and the culture's influence spread to other parts of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a>, throughout the first millennium BC.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalò200951_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalò200951-39">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECookeLiAnderson201146_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECookeLiAnderson201146-41">[35]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dynastic_Vietnam">Dynastic Vietnam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Dynastic Vietnam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_(1009%E2%80%931834).gif" class="image"><img alt="Map showing the territorial expansion of Vietnam between 1009 and 1834" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif/220px-Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="366" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif/330px-Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/85/Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_%281009%E2%80%931834%29.gif 2x" data-file-width="430" data-file-height="715"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Territorial_expansion_of_Vietnam_from_L%C3%BD_dynasty_to_Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty_(1009%E2%80%931834).gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Territorial expansion of Vietnam, 1009–1898
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93ng_B%C3%A0ng_dynasty" title="Hồng Bàng dynasty">Hồng Bàng dynasty</a> of the <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B9ng_kings" class="mw-redirect" title="Hùng kings">Hùng kings</a> first established in 2879 BC is considered the first Vietnamese state in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Vietnam" title="History of Vietnam">History of Vietnam</a> (then known as Xích Quỷ and later <a href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Lang" class="mw-redirect" title="Văn Lang">Văn Lang</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPelley2002151_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPelley2002151-42">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200914_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200914-43">[37]</a></sup> In 257 BC, the last Hùng king was defeated by Thục Phán. He consolidated the <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="Lạc Việt">Lạc Việt</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="Âu Việt">Âu Việt</a> tribes to form the <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_L%E1%BA%A1c" title="Âu Lạc">Âu Lạc</a>, proclaiming himself <a href="/wiki/An_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="An Dương Vương">An Dương Vương</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĐức_TrầnThư_Hà20008_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĐức_TrầnThư_Hà20008-44">[38]</a></sup> In 179 BC, a Chinese general named <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Tuo" title="Zhao Tuo">Zhao Tuo</a> defeated An Dương Vương and consolidated Âu Lạc into <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731-37">[31]</a></sup> However, Nanyue was itself <a href="/wiki/Southward_expansion_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="Southward expansion of the Han dynasty">incorporated into the empire</a> of the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> in 111 BC after the <a href="/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Nanyue_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Han–Nanyue War">Han–Nanyue War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932-23">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYao201662_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYao201662-45">[39]</a></sup> For the next thousand years, what is now northern Vietnam remained mostly under <a href="/wiki/Chinese_domination_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese domination of Vietnam">Chinese rule</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmgren1980_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmgren1980-46">[40]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor198330_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor198330-47">[41]</a></sup> Early independence movements, such as those of the <a href="/wiki/Tr%C6%B0ng_Sisters" class="mw-redirect" title="Trưng Sisters">Trưng Sisters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lady_Tri%E1%BB%87u" title="Lady Triệu">Lady Triệu</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPelley2002177_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPelley2002177-48">[42]</a></sup> were temporarily successful,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200915_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200915-49">[43]</a></sup> though the region gained a longer period of independence as Vạn Xuân under the <a href="/wiki/Anterior_L%C3%BD_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Anterior Lý dynasty">Anterior Lý dynasty</a> between AD 544 and 602.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThái_NguyênMừng_Nguyẽ̂n195833_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThái_NguyênMừng_Nguyẽ̂n195833-50">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChesneaux196620_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChesneaux196620-51">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEanon.197224_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEanon.197224-52">[46]</a></sup> By the early 10th century, Vietnam had gained autonomy, but not sovereignty, under the <a href="/wiki/Kh%C3%BAc_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Khúc family">Khúc family</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuyet_TranReid200632_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuyet_TranReid200632-53">[47]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In AD 938, the Vietnamese lord <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_Quy%E1%BB%81n" title="Ngô Quyền">Ngô Quyền</a> defeated the forces of the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Southern_Han" title="Southern Han">Southern Han</a> state at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_B%E1%BA%A1ch_%C4%90%E1%BA%B1ng_(938)" title="Battle of Bạch Đằng (938)">Bạch Đằng River</a> and achieved full independence for Vietnam after a millennium of Chinese domination.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiẻ̂n_Lê200365_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiẻ̂n_Lê200365-54">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201455_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201455-55">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226-56">[50]</a></sup> Renamed Đại Việt (<i>Great Viet</i>), the nation enjoyed a golden era under the Lý and <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_dynasty" title="Trần dynasty">Trần</a> dynasties. During the rule of the Trần Dynasty, Đại Việt repelled three <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Vietnam" title="Mongol invasions of Vietnam">Mongol invasions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200916_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200916-57">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201495_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201495-58">[52]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a> branch of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhism</a> flourished and became the state religion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226-56">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeyes1995183_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeyes1995183-59">[53]</a></sup> Following the 1406–7 <a href="/wiki/Ming%E2%80%93H%E1%BB%93_War" title="Ming–Hồ War">Ming–Hồ War</a>, which overthrew the <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_dynasty" title="Hồ dynasty">Hồ dynasty</a>, Vietnamese independence was <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Chinese_domination_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Fourth Chinese domination of Vietnam">interrupted briefly</a> by the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>, but was restored by <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_L%E1%BB%A3i" title="Lê Lợi">Lê Lợi</a>, the founder of the <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_dynasty" title="Lê dynasty">Lê dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014111_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014111-60">[54]</a></sup> The Vietnamese dynasties reached their zenith in the Lê dynasty of the 15th century, especially during the reign of Emperor <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Th%C3%A1nh_T%C3%B4ng" title="Lê Thánh Tông">Lê Thánh Tông</a> (1460–1497).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014120_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014120-61">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017265_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017265-62">[56]</a></sup> Between the 11th and 18th centuries, Vietnam expanded southward in a process known as <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text"><a href="/wiki/Nam_ti%E1%BA%BFn" title="Nam tiến">Nam tiến</a></i> ("Southward expansion"),<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014158_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014158-63">[57]</a></sup> eventually conquering the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Champa" title="Champa">Champa</a> and part of the <a href="/wiki/Post-Angkor_Period" title="Post-Angkor Period">Khmer Kingdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201113_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201113-64">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoiAnh_Tuan2015212_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoiAnh_Tuan2015212-65">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639-66">[60]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 16th century onward, civil strife and frequent political infighting engulfed much of Vietnam. First, the Chinese-supported <a href="/wiki/M%E1%BA%A1c_dynasty" title="Mạc dynasty">Mạc dynasty</a> challenged the Lê dynasty's power.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014174_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014174-67">[61]</a></sup> After the Mạc dynasty was defeated, the Lê dynasty was nominally reinstalled. Actual power, however, was divided between the northern <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BB%8Bnh_lords" title="Trịnh lords">Trịnh lords</a> and the southern <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_lords" title="Nguyễn lords">Nguyễn lords</a>, who engaged in a <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%93Nguy%E1%BB%85n_War" title="Trịnh–Nguyễn War">civil war</a> for more than four decades before a truce was called in the 1670s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeonard1984131_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeonard1984131-68">[62]</a></sup> During this period, the Nguyễn expanded southern Vietnam into the <a href="/wiki/Mekong_Delta" title="Mekong Delta">Mekong Delta</a>, annexing the <a href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> and the Khmer lands in the Mekong Delta.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201113_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201113-64">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639-66">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356-69">[63]</a></sup> The division of the country ended a century later when the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A2y_S%C6%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Tây Sơn">Tây Sơn</a> brothers established a new dynasty. However, their rule did not last long, and they were defeated by the remnants of the Nguyễn lords, led by <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Nguyễn Ánh</a>, aided by the French.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPageSonnenburg2003723_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPageSonnenburg2003723-70">[64]</a></sup> Nguyễn Ánh unified Vietnam, and established the <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguyễn dynasty">Nguyễn dynasty</a>, ruling under the name <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Gia Long</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356_69-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356-69">[63]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="French_Indochina">French Indochina</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: French Indochina">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cochinchina_campaign" title="Cochinchina campaign">Cochinchina campaign</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sino-French_War" title="Sino-French War">Sino-French War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_campaign" title="Tonkin campaign">Tonkin campaign</a>, and <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg" class="image"><img alt="1930 Map of French Indochina" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg/250px-French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="369" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg/375px-French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f7/French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg 2x" data-file-width="447" data-file-height="659"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_c._1930.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a> circa 1930.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 1500s, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> became acquainted with the Vietnamese coast, where they reportedly erected a <a href="/wiki/Stele" title="Stele">stele</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A0m_Islands" title="Chàm Islands">Chàm Islands</a> to mark their presence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750-71">[65]</a></sup> By 1533, they began landing in the Vietnamese delta but were forced to leave because of local turmoil and fighting. They also had less interest in the territory than they did in China and Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750_71-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750-71">[65]</a></sup> After having successfully settled <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Macau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Nagasaki" title="Portuguese Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a> to begin the profitable Macau-Japan trade route, the Portuguese began to involve themselves in trade with <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="Hội An">Hội An</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750_71-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750-71">[65]</a></sup> Portuguese traders and <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> missionaries under the <i><a href="/wiki/Padroado" title="Padroado">Padroado</a></i> system were active in both Vietnamese realms of <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0ng_Trong" title="Đàng Trong">Đàng Trong</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Cochinchina" title="Cochinchina">Cochinchina</a> or Quinan) and <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0ng_Ngo%C3%A0i" title="Đàng Ngoài">Đàng Ngoài</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Tonkin" title="Tonkin">Tonkin</a>) in the 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran2018_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran2018-72">[66]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Empire" title="Dutch Empire">Dutch</a> also tried to establish contact with Quinan in 1601 but failed to sustain a presence there after several violent encounters with the locals. The <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> (VOC) only managed to establish official relations with Tonkin in the spring of 1637 after leaving <a href="/wiki/Dejima" title="Dejima">Dejima</a> in Japan to establish trade for <a href="/wiki/Silk" title="Silk">silk</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200752_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200752-73">[67]</a></sup> Meanwhile, in 1613, the first <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">English</a> attempt to establish contact with Hội An failed following a violent incident involving the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">Honourable East India Company</a>. By 1672 the English managed to establish relations with Tonkin and were allowed to reside in <a href="/wiki/H%C6%B0ng_Y%C3%AAn" title="Hưng Yên">Phố Hiến</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200753_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200753-74">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 1615 and 1753, French traders also engaged in trade in Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi199889_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi199889-75">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard2010479_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard2010479-76">[70]</a></sup> The first French missionaries arrived in Vietnam in 1658, under the Portuguese <i>Padroado</i>. From its foundation, the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Foreign_Missions_Society" title="Paris Foreign Missions Society">Paris Foreign Missions Society</a> under <a href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Evangelization_of_Peoples" title="Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples"><i>Propaganda Fide</i></a> actively sent missionaries to Vietnam, entering Cochinchina first in 1664 and Tonkin first in 1666.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran201727_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran201727-77">[71]</a></sup> Spanish <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominicans</a> joined the Tonkin mission in 1676, and <a href="/wiki/Franciscans" title="Franciscans">Franciscans</a> were present in Cochinchina from 1719 to 1834. The Vietnamese authorities began<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (October 2020)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> to feel threatened by continuous <a href="/wiki/Christianisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Christianisation">Christianisation</a> activities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199122_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199122-78">[72]</a></sup> Following the detention of several missionaries, the <a href="/wiki/French_Navy" title="French Navy">French Navy</a> received approval from their government to intervene in Vietnam in 1843, with the aim of freeing imprisoned Catholic missionaries from a kingdom that was perceived as <a href="/wiki/Xenophobic" class="mw-redirect" title="Xenophobic">xenophobic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200242_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200242-79">[73]</a></sup> Vietnam's sovereignty was gradually <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">eroded by France</a> in a series of military conquests between 1859 and 1885.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECortada199429_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECortada199429-80">[74]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Tourane" title="Siege of Tourane">Siege of Tourane</a> in 1858, the French was aided by the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> and perhaps some Tonkinese Catholics.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201246_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201246-81">[75]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saigon_(1862)" title="Treaty of Saigon (1862)">1862 Treaty</a> and especially after the full conquest of <a href="/wiki/Southern_Vietnam" title="Southern Vietnam">Lower Cochinchina</a> by France in 1867, the <a href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Th%C3%A2n_movement" title="Văn Thân movement">Văn Thân movement</a> of scholar-gentry class arose and committed violence against Catholics across central and northern Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201249–50_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201249–50-82">[76]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 1862 and 1867, the southern third of the country became the <a href="/wiki/French_Cochinchina" title="French Cochinchina">French colony of Cochinchina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199161_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199161-83">[77]</a></sup> By 1884, the entire country had come under French rule, with the central and northern parts of Vietnam separated into the two protectorates of <a href="/wiki/Annam_(French_protectorate)" title="Annam (French protectorate)">Annam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_(French_protectorate)" title="Tonkin (French protectorate)">Tonkin</a>. The three Vietnamese entities were formally integrated into the union of <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a> in 1887.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004520_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004520-84">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECook2001396_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECook2001396-85">[79]</a></sup> The French administration imposed significant political and cultural changes on Vietnamese society.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011172_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011172-86">[80]</a></sup> A Western-style system of modern education introduced new <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">humanist</a> values into Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201637_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201637-87">[81]</a></sup> Most French settlers in Indochina were concentrated in Cochinchina, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Saigon" class="mw-redirect" title="Saigon">Saigon</a>, and in <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, the colony's capital.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichardson1876269_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichardson1876269-88">[82]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of the Grand Palais building in Hanoi" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/220px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/330px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/440px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="759" data-file-height="473"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Grand_Palais_(Hanoi)" title="Grand Palais (Hanoi)">Grand Palais</a> built for the 1902–1903 <a href="/wiki/Hanoi_exhibition" class="mw-redirect" title="Hanoi exhibition">world's fair</a> as <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> became French Indochina's capital.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Guerrillas of the royalist <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_movement" title="Cần Vương movement">Cần Vương movement</a> massacred around a third of Vietnam's Christian population during the colonial period as part of their rebellion against French rule.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201253_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201253-89">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh_Ngo201671_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh_Ngo201671-90">[84]</a></sup> They were defeated in the 1890s after a decade of resistance by the Catholics in reprisal for their earlier massacres.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuach_Langlet1991360_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuach_Langlet1991360-91">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamsay2008171_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsay2008171-92">[86]</a></sup> Another large-scale rebellion, the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_Nguy%C3%AAn_uprising" title="Thái Nguyên uprising">Thái Nguyên uprising</a>, was also suppressed heavily.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZinoman2000_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZinoman2000-93">[87]</a></sup> The French developed a <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantation economy</a> to promote the export of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indigo_dye" title="Indigo dye">indigo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">tea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201433_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201433-94">[88]</a></sup> However, they largely ignored the increasing demands for civil rights and <a href="/wiki/Self-government" class="mw-redirect" title="Self-government">self-government</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Theatre.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of the Hanoi Opera House viewed from rue Paul Bert (now Trang Tien Street" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Hanoi_Theatre.JPG/220px-Hanoi_Theatre.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Hanoi_Theatre.JPG/330px-Hanoi_Theatre.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Hanoi_Theatre.JPG/440px-Hanoi_Theatre.JPG 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="427"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Theatre.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Hanoi_Opera_House" title="Hanoi Opera House">Hanoi Opera House</a>, taken in the early 20th century, from rue <a href="/wiki/Paul_Bert" title="Paul Bert">Paul Bert</a> (now Trang Tien street).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A nationalist political movement soon emerged, with leaders like <a href="/wiki/Phan_B%E1%BB%99i_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Phan Bội Châu">Phan Bội Châu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phan_Ch%C3%A2u_Trinh" class="mw-redirect" title="Phan Châu Trinh">Phan Châu Trinh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phan_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Ph%C3%B9ng" title="Phan Đình Phùng">Phan Đình Phùng</a>, Emperor <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0m_Nghi" title="Hàm Nghi">Hàm Nghi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" class="mw-redirect" title="Hồ Chí Minh">Hồ Chí Minh</a> fighting or calling for independence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo2002112_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo2002112-95">[89]</a></sup> This resulted in the 1930 <a href="/wiki/Y%C3%AAn_B%C3%A1i_mutiny" title="Yên Bái mutiny">Yên Bái mutiny</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Nam_Qu%E1%BB%91c_D%C3%A2n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3ng" title="Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng">Vietnamese Nationalist Party</a> (VNQDĐ), which the French quashed. The mutiny caused an irreparable split in the independence movement that resulted in many leading members of the organisation becoming <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> converts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhánh_Huỳnh198698_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhánh_Huỳnh198698-96">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOdellCastillo200882_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOdellCastillo200882-97">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2012_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2012-98">[92]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The French maintained full control over their colonies until World War II, when the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">war in the Pacific</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina" title="Japanese invasion of French Indochina">Japanese invasion of French Indochina</a> in 1940. Afterwards, the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a> was allowed to station its troops in Vietnam while permitting the pro-<a href="/wiki/Vichy_France" title="Vichy France">Vichy French</a> colonial administration to continue.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller1990293_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller1990293-99">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGettlemanFranklinYoungFranklin19954_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGettlemanFranklinYoungFranklin19954-100">[94]</a></sup> Japan exploited Vietnam's natural resources to support its military campaigns, culminating in a <a href="/wiki/Japanese_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_in_French_Indochina" title="Japanese coup d'état in French Indochina">full-scale takeover of the country</a> in March 1945. This led to the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Famine_of_1945" class="mw-redirect" title="Vietnamese Famine of 1945">Vietnamese Famine of 1945</a>, which resulted in up to two million deaths.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Niên2015_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Niên2015-101">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2015_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2015-102">[96]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Indochina_War">First Indochina War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: First Indochina War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">Empire of Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam" title="State of Vietnam">State of Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Passage_to_Freedom" title="Operation Passage to Freedom">Operation Passage to Freedom</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg" class="image"><img alt="Map of the First Indochina Wa4, 1954" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg/220px-First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="312" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg/330px-First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg/440px-First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="580" data-file-height="822"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:First_Indochina_War_map_1954_en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Situation of the <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a> at the end of 1954.
         <br>
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#EEA270; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Areas under <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Minh" class="mw-redirect" title="Việt Minh">Việt Minh</a> control
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#D3B2DB; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Areas under <a href="/wiki/French_Foreign_Legion" title="French Foreign Legion">French</a> control
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#00000; color:;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Việt Minh guerrilla encampment / fighting
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1941, the <a href="/wiki/Viet_Minh" title="Viet Minh">Việt Minh</a>, a nationalist liberation movement based on a <a href="/wiki/Communist_Ideology" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist Ideology">Communist Ideology</a>, emerged under the Vietnamese revolutionary leader <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" class="mw-redirect" title="Hồ Chí Minh">Hồ Chí Minh</a>. The Việt Minh sought independence for Vietnam from France and the end of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese occupation of Vietnam">Japanese occupation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJoes199295_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJoes199295-103">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-104">[98]</a></sup> Following the military defeat of Japan and the fall of its puppet <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">Empire of Vietnam</a> in August 1945, anarchy, rioting, and murder were widespread, as Saigon's administrative services had collapsed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGunn2014270_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGunn2014270-105">[99]</a></sup> The Việt Minh occupied <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> and proclaimed a provisional government, which asserted national independence on 2 September.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_104-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-104">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In July 1945, the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> had decided to divide Indochina at the <a href="/wiki/16th_parallel_north" title="16th parallel north">16th parallel</a> to allow <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a> to receive the Japanese surrender in the north while Britain's <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a> received their surrender in the south. The Allies agreed that Indochina still belonged to France.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville2007175_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville2007175-106">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith20076_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith20076-107">[101]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>But as the French were weakened by the <a href="/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II" title="German military administration in occupied France during World War II">German occupation</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British-Indian</a> forces and the remaining Japanese <a href="/wiki/Southern_Expeditionary_Army_Group" title="Southern Expeditionary Army Group">Southern Expeditionary Army Group</a> were used to maintain order and to help France reestablish control through the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Vietnam_(1945%E2%80%9346)" class="mw-redirect" title="War in Vietnam (1945–46)">1945–1946 War in Vietnam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville2007124_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville2007124-108">[102]</a></sup> Hồ initially chose to take a moderate stance to avoid military conflict with France, asking the French to withdraw their colonial administrators and for French professors and engineers to help build a modern independent Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_104-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-104">[98]</a></sup> But the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_French_Republic" title="Provisional Government of the French Republic">Provisional Government of the French Republic</a> did not act on these requests, including the idea of independence, and dispatched the <a href="/wiki/French_Far_East_Expeditionary_Corps" title="French Far East Expeditionary Corps">French Far East Expeditionary Corps</a> to restore colonial rule. This resulted in the Việt Minh launching a guerrilla campaign against the French in late 1946.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJoes199295_103-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJoes199295-103">[97]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_104-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-104">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnesson201166_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnesson201166-109">[103]</a></sup> The resulting <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a> lasted until July 1954. The defeat of French colonialists and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_National_Army" title="Vietnamese National Army">Vietnamese loyalists</a> in the 1954 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Ph%E1%BB%A7" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Điện Biên Phủ">battle of Điện Biên Phủ</a> allowed Hồ to negotiate a ceasefire from a favourable position at the subsequent <a href="/wiki/1954_Geneva_Conference" title="1954 Geneva Conference">Geneva Conference</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_104-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-104">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaite201289_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaite201289-110">[104]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_post_partition.png" class="image"><img alt="Map showing the partition of French Indochina following the 1954 Geneva Conference" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/French_Indochina_post_partition.png/220px-French_Indochina_post_partition.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="335" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/French_Indochina_post_partition.png 1.5x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="457"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_post_partition.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Partition_(politics)" title="Partition (politics)">Partition</a> of French Indochina after the <a href="/wiki/1954_Geneva_Conference" title="1954 Geneva Conference">1954 Geneva Conference</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The colonial administration was thereby ended and French Indochina was dissolved under the Geneva Accords of 1954 into three countries—Vietnam, and the kingdoms of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Cambodia_(1953%E2%80%931970)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Cambodia (1953–1970)">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>. Vietnam was further divided into North and South administrative regions at the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone">Demilitarised Zone</a>, roughly along the <a href="/wiki/17th_parallel_north" title="17th parallel north">17th parallel north</a>, pending elections scheduled for July 1956.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[n 7]</a></sup> A 300-day period of free movement was permitted, during which almost a million northerners, mainly Catholics, moved south, fearing persecution by the communists. This migration was in large part aided by the United States military through <a href="/wiki/Operation_Passage_to_Freedom" title="Operation Passage to Freedom">Operation Passage to Freedom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlson201243_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlson201243-116">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDK201739_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDK201739-117">[110]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Partition of Vietnam">partition of Vietnam</a> by the Geneva Accords was not intended to be permanent, and stipulated that Vietnam would be reunited after the elections.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-118">[111]</a></sup> But in 1955, the southern State of Vietnam's prime minister, <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" class="mw-redirect" title="Ngô Đình Diệm">Ngô Đình Diệm</a>, toppled <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%A3o_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i" title="Bảo Đại">Bảo Đại</a> in a fraudulent <a href="/wiki/1955_State_of_Vietnam_referendum" title="1955 State of Vietnam referendum">referendum</a> organised by his brother <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Nhu" title="Ngô Đình Nhu">Ngô Đình Nhu</a>, and proclaimed himself president of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Vietnam">Republic of Vietnam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_118-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-118">[111]</a></sup> At that point the internationally recognised <a href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam" title="State of Vietnam">State of Vietnam</a> effectively ceased to exist and was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Vietnam">Republic of Vietnam</a> in the south—supported by the United States, France, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a> and Thailand—and Hồ's <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a> in the north, supported by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, Sweden,<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[112]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Republic of China">People's Republic of China</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_118-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-118">[111]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vietnam_War">Vietnam War</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Vietnam War">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Role_of_the_United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Role of the United States in the Vietnam War">Role of the United States in the Vietnam War</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Between 1953 and 1956, the North Vietnamese government instituted various <a href="/wiki/Agrarianism" title="Agrarianism">agrarian</a> reforms, including "<a href="/wiki/Rent_regulation" title="Rent regulation">rent reduction</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Land_reform_in_Vietnam" title="Land reform in Vietnam">land reform</a>", which resulted in significant <a href="/wiki/Political_repression" title="Political repression">political repression</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoïse201756_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoïse201756-120">[113]</a></sup> During the land reform, testimony from North Vietnamese witnesses suggested a ratio of one execution for every 160 village residents, which extrapolated nationwide would indicate nearly 100,000 executions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975143_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975143-121">[114]</a></sup> Because the campaign was concentrated mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Delta" class="mw-redirect" title="Red River Delta">Red River Delta</a> area, a lower estimate of 50,000 executions became widely accepted by scholars at the time,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975143_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975143-121">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGittinger1959_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGittinger1959-122">[115]</a></sup> but declassified documents from the Vietnamese and Hungarian archives indicate that the number of executions was much lower, although likely greater than 13,500.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVu2007_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVu2007-123">[116]</a></sup> In the South, Diệm countered North Vietnamese subversion (including the assassination of over 450 South Vietnamese officials in 1956) by detaining tens of thousands of suspected communists in "political reeducation centres".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeneghan1969160_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeneghan1969160-124">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975177_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975177-125">[118]</a></sup> This program incarcerated many non-communists, but was successful at curtailing communist activity in the country, if only for a time.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrozier1955_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrozier1955-126">[119]</a></sup> The North Vietnamese government claimed that 2,148 people were killed in the process by November 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975174–178_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975174–178-127">[120]</a></sup> The pro-Hanoi <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_C%E1%BB%99ng" class="mw-redirect" title="Việt Cộng">Việt Cộng</a> began a guerrilla campaign in South Vietnam in the late 1950s to overthrow Diệm's government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilbert2013292_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert2013292-128">[121]</a></sup> From 1960, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and North Vietnam signed treaties providing for further Soviet military support.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209-129">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792-130">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhoo201127_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhoo201127-131">[124]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Three US Fairchild UC-123B aircraft pictured spraying Agent Orange" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/220px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="207" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/330px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/440px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg 2x" data-file-width="509" data-file-height="480"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Three US <a href="/wiki/Fairchild_C-123_Provider" title="Fairchild C-123 Provider">Fairchild UC-123B</a> aircraft spraying <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Ranch_Hand" title="Operation Ranch Hand">Operation Ranch Hand</a> as part of the overall <a href="/wiki/Herbicidal_warfare" title="Herbicidal warfare">herbicidal warfare</a> operation called Trail Dust with the aim to deprive the food and vegetation cover of the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_C%E1%BB%99ng" class="mw-redirect" title="Việt Cộng">Việt Cộng</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1962–1971</span>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1963, Buddhist discontent with Diệm's Catholic regime erupted into <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_crisis" title="Buddhist crisis">mass demonstrations</a>, leading to a violent government crackdown.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuehlenbeckMuehlenbeck2012221_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuehlenbeckMuehlenbeck2012221-132">[125]</a></sup> This led to the <a href="/wiki/Cable_243" title="Cable 243">collapse of Diệm's relationship with the United States</a>, and ultimately to a <a href="/wiki/1963_South_Vietnamese_coup" title="1963 South Vietnamese coup">1963 coup</a> in which <a href="/wiki/Arrest_and_assassination_of_Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" class="mw-redirect" title="Arrest and assassination of Ngô Đình Diệm">he and Nhu were assassinated</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillbanks201353_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillbanks201353-133">[126]</a></sup> The Diệm era was followed by more than a dozen successive military governments, before the pairing of Air Marshal <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Cao_K%E1%BB%B3" title="Nguyễn Cao Kỳ">Nguyễn Cao Kỳ</a> and General <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Thi%E1%BB%87u" title="Nguyễn Văn Thiệu">Nguyễn Văn Thiệu</a> took control in mid-1965.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuy_HinhDinh_Tho2015238_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuy_HinhDinh_Tho2015238-134">[127]</a></sup> Thiệu gradually outmaneuvered Kỳ and cemented his grip on power in fraudulent elections in 1967 and 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIssermanBowman200946_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIssermanBowman200946-135">[128]</a></sup> During this political instability, the communists began to gain ground. To support South Vietnam's struggle against the communist insurgency, the United States began increasing its contribution of military advisers, using the 1964 <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin_incident" title="Gulf of Tonkin incident">Gulf of Tonkin incident</a> as a pretext for such intervention.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlterman2005213_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlterman2005213-136">[129]</a></sup> US forces became involved in ground combat operations by 1965, and at their peak several years later, numbered more than 500,000.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewy1980_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewy1980-137">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibbons2014166_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibbons2014166-138">[131]</a></sup> The US also engaged in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Rolling_Thunder" title="Operation Rolling Thunder">a sustained aerial bombing campaign</a>. Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and the Soviet Union provided North Vietnam with significant material aid and 15,000 combat advisers.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209-129">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792-130">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi201267_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi201267-139">[132]</a></sup> Communist forces supplying the Việt Cộng carried supplies along the <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_trail" title="Ho Chi Minh trail">Hồ Chí Minh trail</a>, which passed through <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGillet2011_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGillet2011-140">[133]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The communists attacked South Vietnamese targets during the 1968 <a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt_Offensive" class="mw-redirect" title="Tết Offensive">Tết Offensive</a>. The campaign failed militarily, but shocked the American establishment and turned US public opinion against the war.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2018_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2018-141">[134]</a></sup> During the offensive, communist troops <a href="/wiki/Massacre_at_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Massacre at Huế">massacred over 3,000 civilians</a> at <a href="/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Huế">Huế</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975251_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975251-142">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011209_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrankum_Jr.2011209-143">[136]</a></sup> A 1974 US Senate subcommittee estimated nearly 1.4&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War_casualties" title="Vietnam War casualties">Vietnamese civilians</a> were killed or wounded between 1965 and 1974—over half as the result of US and South Vietnamese military actions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDohrenwendTurseWallYager201869_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDohrenwendTurseWallYager201869-144">[137]</a></sup> Facing an increasing casualty count, <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War">rising domestic opposition</a> to the war, and growing international condemnation, the US began <a href="/wiki/Nixon_Doctrine" title="Nixon Doctrine">withdrawing from ground combat roles</a> in the early 1970s. This also entailed an unsuccessful effort to <a href="/wiki/Vietnamisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Vietnamisation">strengthen and stabilise South Vietnam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEggleston20141_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEggleston20141-145">[138]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords" title="Paris Peace Accords">Paris Peace Accords</a> of 27 January 1973, all American combat troops were withdrawn by 29 March 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHistory2018_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHistory2018-146">[139]</a></sup> In December 1974, North Vietnam <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long" title="Battle of Phước Long">captured</a> the province of <a href="/wiki/Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long_Province" title="Phước Long Province">Phước Long</a> and started a <a href="/wiki/1975_Spring_Offensive" title="1975 Spring Offensive">full-scale offensive</a>, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">fall of Saigon</a> on 30 April 1975.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETucker2011749_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETucker2011749-147">[140]</a></sup> South Vietnam was ruled by a <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam" title="Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam">provisional government</a> for almost eight years while under North Vietnamese military occupation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrigham199886_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrigham199886-148">[141]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reunification_and_reforms">Reunification and reforms</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Reunification and reforms">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Re-education_camp_(Vietnam)" title="Re-education camp (Vietnam)">Re-education camp (Vietnam)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_boat_people" title="Vietnamese boat people">Vietnamese boat people</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">Đổi Mới</a>
      </div> 
      <p>On 2 July 1976, North and South Vietnam were merged to form the Socialist Republic of Việt Nam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_New_York_Times''1976_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_New_York_Times''1976-149">[142]</a></sup> The war left Vietnam devastated, with the total death toll between 966,000 and 3.8&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirschmanPrestonManh_Loi1995_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirschmanPrestonManh_Loi1995-150">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShenon1995_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShenon1995-151">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEObermeyerMurrayGakidou2008_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEObermeyerMurrayGakidou2008-152">[145]</a></sup> In its aftermath, under <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Du%E1%BA%A9n" title="Lê Duẩn">Lê Duẩn</a>'s administration, there were no mass executions of South Vietnamese who had collaborated with the US or the defunct South Vietnamese government, confounding Western fears,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElliott2010499,_512–513_153-0"
