               <hr> <p>4. <a href="/wiki/Da_Nang" title="Da Nang">Đà Nẵng</a> (municipality)<br> 39. <a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh_Province" title="Bình Định Province">Bình Định</a><br> 46. <a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Thu%E1%BA%ADn_Province" title="Bình Thuận Province">Bình Thuận</a><br> 43. <a href="/wiki/Kh%C3%A1nh_H%C3%B2a_Province" title="Khánh Hòa Province">Khánh Hòa</a><br> 45. <a href="/wiki/Ninh_Thu%E1%BA%ADn_Province" title="Ninh Thuận Province">Ninh Thuận</a><br> 40. <a href="/wiki/Ph%C3%BA_Y%C3%AAn_Province" title="Phú Yên Province">Phú Yên</a><br> 35. <a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Nam_Province" title="Quảng Nam Province">Quảng Nam</a><br> 36. <a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Ng%C3%A3i_Province" title="Quảng Ngãi Province">Quảng Ngãi</a> </p> </td>
             </tr> 
             <tr> 
              <td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;"> 
               <div class="center">
                <b><a href="/wiki/Southeast_(Vietnam)" title="Southeast (Vietnam)">Southeast</a></b>
               </div> 
               <hr> <p>2. <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Hồ Chí Minh City</a> (municipality)<br> 51. <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A0_R%E1%BB%8Ba%E2%80%93V%C5%A9ng_T%C3%A0u_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Bà Rịa–Vũng Tàu Province">Bà Rịa–Vũng Tàu</a><br> 49. <a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_Province" title="Bình Dương Province">Bình Dương</a><br> 47. <a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Province" title="Bình Phước Province">Bình Phước</a><br> 50. <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng_Nai_Province" title="Đồng Nai Province">Đồng Nai</a><br> 48. <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A2y_Ninh_Province" title="Tây Ninh Province">Tây Ninh</a> </p> </td> 
              <td style="padding-right:1em; vertical-align:top;"> 
               <div class="center">
                <b><a href="/wiki/Mekong_Delta" title="Mekong Delta">Mekong Delta</a></b>
               </div> 
               <hr> <p>5. <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Th%C6%A1" title="Cần Thơ">Cần Thơ</a> (municipality)<br> 56. <a href="/wiki/An_Giang_Province" title="An Giang Province">An Giang</a><br> 62. <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%A1c_Li%C3%AAu_Province" title="Bạc Liêu Province">Bạc Liêu</a><br> 55. <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%BFn_Tre_Province" title="Bến Tre Province">Bến Tre</a><br> 63. <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A0_Mau_Province" title="Cà Mau Province">Cà Mau</a><br> 53. <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%93ng_Th%C3%A1p_Province" title="Đồng Tháp Province">Đồng Tháp</a><br> 59. <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%ADu_Giang_Province" title="Hậu Giang Province">Hậu Giang</a><br> 58. <a href="/wiki/Ki%C3%AAn_Giang_Province" title="Kiên Giang Province">Kiên Giang</a><br> 52. <a href="/wiki/Long_An_Province" title="Long An Province">Long An</a><br> 61. <a href="/wiki/S%C3%B3c_Tr%C4%83ng_Province" title="Sóc Trăng Province">Sóc Trăng</a><br> 54. <a href="/wiki/Ti%E1%BB%81n_Giang_Province" title="Tiền Giang Province">Tiền Giang</a><br> 60. <a href="/wiki/Tr%C3%A0_Vinh_Province" title="Trà Vinh Province">Trà Vinh</a><br> 57. <a href="/wiki/V%C4%A9nh_Long_Province" title="Vĩnh Long Province">Vĩnh Long</a> </p> </td>
             </tr>
            </tbody>
           </table> <p> </p> </td>
         </tr>
        </tbody>
       </table>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A Tay Ho Communist propaganda poster" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg/220px-Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg/330px-Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg/440px-Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="1728"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tay_Ho_Communist_propaganda_posters_in_2015_11.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party</a> propaganda poster in Hanoi
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The provinces are subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Provincial_city_(Vietnam)" title="Provincial city (Vietnam)">provincial municipalities</a> (<i>thành phố trực thuộc tỉnh</i>), <a href="/wiki/Township" title="Township">townships</a> (<i>thị xã</i>) and <a href="/wiki/County" title="County">counties</a> (<i>huyện</i>), which are in turn subdivided into towns (<i>thị trấn</i>) or <a href="/wiki/Commune-level_subdivisions_(Vietnam)" title="Commune-level subdivisions (Vietnam)">communes</a> (<i>xã</i>). The centrally controlled municipalities are subdivided into <a href="/wiki/District" title="District">districts</a> (<i>quận</i>) and counties, which are further subdivided into <a href="/wiki/Ward_(country_subdivision)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ward (country subdivision)">wards</a> (<i>phường</i>). </p>
      <p><br> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Economy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Vietnam" title="Economy of Vietnam">Economy of Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="text-align:center; background:#cfb;" colspan="2">Share of world <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> (<a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_11-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-11">[7]</a></sup> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Year </th> 
         <th style="background:#cfb;">Share </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>1980</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.18% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>1990</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.23% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2000</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.32% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2010</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.43% </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td>2018</td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">0.52% </td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png" class="image"><img alt="A tree map of Vietnam's exports in 2012" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png/220px-Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="172" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png/330px-Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png/440px-Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png 2x" data-file-width="961" data-file-height="751"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Viet_Nam_Export_Treemap.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tree_map" class="mw-redirect" title="Tree map">Tree map</a> showing Vietnam's exports in 2012
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Throughout the history of Vietnam, its economy has been based largely on <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>—primarily <a href="/wiki/Rice_production_in_Vietnam" title="Rice production in Vietnam">wet rice cultivation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECornell_University_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECornell_University-264">[255]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bauxite_mining_in_Vietnam" title="Bauxite mining in Vietnam">Bauxite</a>, an important material in the production of <a href="/wiki/Aluminium" title="Aluminium">aluminium</a>, is mined in central Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKim_Phuong20141_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKim_Phuong20141-265">[256]</a></sup> Since reunification, the country's economy is shaped primarily by the CPV through <a href="/wiki/Five-Year_Plans_of_Vietnam" title="Five-Year Plans of Vietnam">Five Year Plans</a> decided upon at the plenary sessions of the Central Committee and national congresses.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKimura1986_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKimura1986-266">[257]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Collectivisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivisation">collectivisation</a> of farms, factories, and capital goods was carried out as part of the establishment of central planning, with millions of people working for state enterprises. Under strict state control, Vietnam's economy continued to be plagued by inefficiency, <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Vietnam" title="Corruption in Vietnam">corruption in state-owned enterprises</a>, poor quality and underproduction.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdhikariKirkpatrickWeiss1992249_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdhikariKirkpatrickWeiss1992249-267">[258]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENgoc_VoLe20147_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENgoc_VoLe20147-268">[259]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho200311_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho200311-269">[260]</a></sup> With the decline in economic aid from its main trading partner, the Soviet Union, following the erosion of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_bloc" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern bloc">Eastern bloc</a> in the late 1980s, and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">collapse of the Soviet Union</a>, as well as the negative impacts of the post-war <a href="/wiki/Economic_sanctions" title="Economic sanctions">trade embargo</a> imposed by the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199931_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199931-270">[261]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreeman2002_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreeman2002-271">[262]</a></sup> Vietnam began to liberalise its trade by <a href="/wiki/Devaluation" title="Devaluation">devaluing</a> its exchange rate to increase exports and embarked on a policy of economic development.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199933_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELitvackLitvackRondinelli199933-272">[263]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of Vietnam's tallest skyscraper, the Landmark 81, located in Bình Thạnh District in Ho Chi Minh City" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg/220px-The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg/330px-The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg/440px-The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3024" data-file-height="4032"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_Landmark_81_at_night.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Vietnam's tallest skyscraper, the <a href="/wiki/Landmark_81" title="Landmark 81">Landmark 81</a> located in <a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Th%E1%BA%A1nh_District" title="Bình Thạnh District">Bình Thạnh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1986, the <a href="/wiki/6th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="6th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam">Sixth National Congress</a> of the CPV introduced <a href="/wiki/Socialist-oriented_market_economy" title="Socialist-oriented market economy">socialist-oriented market</a> economic reforms as part of the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">Đổi Mới</a></i> reform program. <a href="/wiki/Private_ownership" class="mw-redirect" title="Private ownership">Private ownership</a> began to be encouraged in industry, commerce and agriculture and state enterprises were <a href="/wiki/Corporatisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Corporatisation">restructured</a> to operate under market constraints.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035-273">[264]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoang_VuongDung_Tran2009_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoang_VuongDung_Tran2009-274">[265]</a></sup> This led to the five-year economic plans being replaced by the socialist-oriented market mechanism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoang_Vuong2014_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoang_Vuong2014-275">[266]</a></sup> As a result of these reforms, Vietnam achieved approximately 8% annual <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> (GDP) growth between 1990 and 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo200266_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo200266-276">[267]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund199923_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund199923-277">[268]</a></sup> The United States ended its economic embargo against Vietnam in early 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECockburn1994_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECockburn1994-278">[269]</a></sup> Despite the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a> affecting Vietnam by causing an economic slowdown to 4–5% growth per annum, its economy began to recover in 1999,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035_273-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Tho20035-273">[264]</a></sup> with growth at an annual rate of around 7% from 2000 to 2005 making it one of the world's fastest growing economies.<sup id="cite_ref-Pincus2015_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pincus2015-279">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuang_Vinh13_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuang_Vinh13-280">[271]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/General_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam" title="General Statistics Office of Vietnam">General Statistics Office of Vietnam</a> (GSO), growth remained strong even in the face of the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_global_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s global recession">late-2000s global recession</a>, holding at 6.8% in 2010, although Vietnam's year-on-year inflation rate hit 11.8% in December 2010 with the country's currency, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_%C4%91%E1%BB%93ng" title="Vietnamese đồng">Vietnamese đồng</a> being devalued three times.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAsian_Development_Bank2010388_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsian_Development_Bank2010388-281">[272]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Niên2010_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Niên2010-282">[273]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Deep <a href="/wiki/Poverty" title="Poverty">poverty</a>, defined as the percentage of the population living on less than $1 per day, has declined significantly in Vietnam and the relative poverty rate is now less than that of China, India and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVierraVierra20115_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVierraVierra20115-283">[274]</a></sup> This decline can be attributed to <a href="/wiki/Equity_(economics)" title="Equity (economics)">equitable economic policies</a> aimed at improving <a href="/wiki/Living_standards" class="mw-redirect" title="Living standards">living standards</a> and preventing the rise of <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">inequality</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010-284">[275]</a></sup> These policies have included egalitarian land distribution during the initial stages of the <i>Đổi Mới</i> program, investment in poorer remote areas, and subsidising of education and healthcare.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023-285">[276]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEH._DangGlewwe20179_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEH._DangGlewwe20179-286">[277]</a></sup> Since the early 2000s, Vietnam has applied sequenced trade liberalisation, a two-track approach opening some sectors of the economy to international markets.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVandemoorteleBird2010-284">[275]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVandemoortele2010_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVandemoortele2010-287">[278]</a></sup> Manufacturing, <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> and high-tech industries now form a large and fast-growing part of the national economy. Though Vietnam is a relative newcomer to the <a href="/wiki/Oil_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil industry">oil industry</a>, it is currently the third-largest oil producer in Southeast Asia with a total 2011 output of 318,000 barrels per day (50,600&nbsp;m<sup>3</sup>/d).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUPI.com2013_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUPI.com2013-288">[279]</a></sup> In 2010, Vietnam was ranked as the eighth-largest crude <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a> producer in the Asia and Pacific region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFong-Sam201026_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFong-Sam201026-289">[280]</a></sup> The United States purchased the highest amount of Vietnam's exports,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018b_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018b-290">[281]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Goods" title="Goods">goods</a> from China were the most popular Vietnamese import.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_News_Agency2018_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_News_Agency2018-291">[282]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a December 2005 forecast by <a href="/wiki/Goldman_Sachs" title="Goldman Sachs">Goldman Sachs</a>, the Vietnamese economy will become the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_past_and_future_GDP_(nominal)" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by past and future GDP (nominal)">world's 21st-largest by 2025</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarmel20101_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarmel20101-292">[283]</a></sup> with an estimated nominal GDP of $436&nbsp;billion and a nominal GDP per capita of $4,357.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELyimo2016_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELyimo2016-293">[284]</a></sup> Based on findings by the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> (IMF) in 2012, the <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">unemployment</a> rate in Vietnam stood at 4.46%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_11-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-11">[7]</a></sup> That same year, Vietnam's <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> reached US$138&nbsp;billion, with a nominal <a href="/wiki/GDP_per_capita" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP per capita">GDP per capita</a> of $1,527.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_11-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-11">[7]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/HSBC" title="HSBC">HSBC</a> also predicted that Vietnam's total GDP would surpass those of <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, Singapore and <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELyimo2016_293-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELyimo2016-293">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Tuổi_Trẻ_News''2012_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Tuổi_Trẻ_News''2012-294">[285]</a></sup> Another forecast by <a href="/wiki/PricewaterhouseCoopers" title="PricewaterhouseCoopers">PricewaterhouseCoopers</a> in 2008 stated Vietnam could be the fastest-growing of the world's emerging economies by 2025, with a potential growth rate of almost 10% per annum in real dollar terms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPWC2008_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPWC2008-295">[286]</a></sup> Apart from the <a href="/wiki/Primary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Primary sector of the economy">primary sector economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Vietnam" title="Tourism in Vietnam">tourism</a> has contributed significantly to Vietnam's economic growth with 7.94&nbsp;million foreign visitors recorded in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2016a_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2016a-296">[287]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Agriculture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of terraced rice fields in Sa Pa" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg/220px-Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg/330px-Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg/440px-Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Terraced_fields_Sa_Pa_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Terraced rice fields in <a href="/wiki/Sa_Pa" title="Sa Pa">Sa Pa</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As a result of several <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a> measures, Vietnam has become a major exporter of agricultural products. It is now the world's largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Cashew" title="Cashew">cashew</a> nuts, with a one-third global share;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMai2017_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMai2017-297">[288]</a></sup> the largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Black_pepper" title="Black pepper">black pepper</a>, accounting for one-third of the world's market;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018c_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018c-298">[289]</a></sup> and the second-largest <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> exporter in the world after <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> since the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENielsen20071_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENielsen20071-299">[290]</a></sup> Subsequently, Vietnam is also the world's second largest exporter of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESummers2014_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESummers2014-300">[291]</a></sup> The country has the highest proportion of land use for <a href="/wiki/Permanent_crop" title="Permanent crop">permanent crops</a> together with other nations in the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Mekong_Subregion" title="Greater Mekong Subregion">Greater Mekong Subregion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETruongVoNguyen2018172_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETruongVoNguyen2018172-301">[292]</a></sup> Other primary exports include <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">tea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rubber" class="mw-redirect" title="Rubber">rubber</a> and fishery products. Agriculture's share of Vietnam's GDP has fallen in recent decades, declining from 42% in 1989 to 20% in 2006 as production in other sectors of the economy has risen. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Science and technology">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Vietnam" title="Science and technology in Vietnam">Science and technology in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:TOPIO_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of a TOPIO humanoid ping-pong-playing robot" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/TOPIO_3.jpg/220px-TOPIO_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/TOPIO_3.jpg/330px-TOPIO_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/TOPIO_3.jpg/440px-TOPIO_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2042" data-file-height="1362"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:TOPIO_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A Vietnamese-made <a href="/wiki/TOPIO" title="TOPIO">TOPIO</a> 3.0 <a href="/wiki/Humanoid_robot" title="Humanoid robot">humanoid</a> <a href="/wiki/Ping-pong" class="mw-redirect" title="Ping-pong">ping-pong</a>-playing robot displayed during the 2009 <a href="/wiki/International_Robot_Exhibition" title="International Robot Exhibition">International Robot Exhibition</a> (IREX) in <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007-302">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorel2010_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorel2010-303">[294]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2010, Vietnam's total state spending on science and technology amounted to roughly 0.45% of its GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2010_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2010-304">[295]</a></sup> Since the dynastic era, Vietnamese scholars have developed many academic fields especially in <a href="/wiki/Social_science" title="Social science">social sciences</a> and humanities. Vietnam has a millennium-deep legacy of analytical histories, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Vi%E1%BB%87t_s%E1%BB%AD_k%C3%BD_to%C3%A0n_th%C6%B0" title="Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư">Đại Việt sử ký toàn thư</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_S%C4%A9_Li%C3%AAn" title="Ngô Sĩ Liên">Ngô Sĩ Liên</a>. Vietnamese monks, led by the abdicated Emperor <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_Nh%C3%A2n_T%C3%B4ng" title="Trần Nhân Tông">Trần Nhân Tông</a>, developed the Trúc Lâm Zen branch of philosophy in the 13th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERóżycka-TranAnh_Tran2014123_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERóżycka-TranAnh_Tran2014123-305">[296]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arithmetic" title="Arithmetic">Arithmetic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geometry" title="Geometry">geometry</a> have been widely taught in Vietnam since the 15th century, using the textbook <i>Đại thành toán pháp</i> by Lương Thế Vinh. Lương Thế Vinh introduced Vietnam to the notion of <a href="/wiki/0_(number)" class="mw-redirect" title="0 (number)">zero</a>, while Mạc Hiển Tích used the term <i>số ẩn</i> (Eng: "unknown/secret/hidden number") to refer to <a href="/wiki/Negative_number" title="Negative number">negative numbers</a>. Furthermore, Vietnamese scholars produced numerous <a href="/wiki/Encyclopaedia" class="mw-redirect" title="Encyclopaedia">encyclopaedias</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Qu%C3%BD_%C4%90%C3%B4n" title="Lê Quý Đôn">Lê Quý Đôn</a>'s <i>Vân đài loại ngữ</i>. </p>
      <p>In modern times, Vietnamese scientists have made many significant contributions in various fields of study, most notably in <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a>. <a href="/wiki/Hoang_Tuy" class="mw-redirect" title="Hoang Tuy">Hoàng Tụy</a> pioneered the <a href="/wiki/Applied_mathematics" title="Applied mathematics">applied mathematics</a> field of <a href="/wiki/Global_optimisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Global optimisation">global optimisation</a> in the 20th century,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoblitz2009198_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoblitz2009198-306">[297]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_B%E1%BA%A3o_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Ngô Bảo Châu">Ngô Bảo Châu</a> won the 2010 <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a> for his proof of <a href="/wiki/Fundamental_lemma_(Langlands_program)" title="Fundamental lemma (Langlands program)">fundamental lemma in the theory of automorphic forms</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECNRS2010_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECNRS2010-307">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoppes2010_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoppes2010-308">[299]</a></sup> Since the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Academy_of_Science_and_Technology" title="Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology">Vietnam Academy of Science and Technology</a> (VAST) by the government in 1975, the country is working to develop its first national <a href="/wiki/Space_flight" class="mw-redirect" title="Space flight">space flight</a> program especially after the completion of the infrastructure at the Vietnam Space Centre (VSC) in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Space_Centre2016_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Space_Centre2016-309">[300]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Academy_of_Science_and_Technology2017_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Academy_of_Science_and_Technology2017-310">[301]</a></sup> Vietnam has also made significant advances in the development of <a href="/wiki/Robot" title="Robot">robots</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/TOPIO" title="TOPIO">TOPIO</a> humanoid model.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007_302-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDigInfo2007-302">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBorel2010_303-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBorel2010-303">[294]</a></sup> One of Vietnam's main <a href="/wiki/Messaging_apps" title="Messaging apps">messaging apps</a>, Zalo, was developed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_Quang_Kh%E1%BA%A3i&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vương Quang Khải (page does not exist)">Vương Quang Khải</a>, a Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Hacker" title="Hacker">hacker</a> who later worked with the country's largest <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> service company, the <a href="/wiki/FPT_Group" title="FPT Group">FPT Group</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERaslan2017_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERaslan2017-311">[302]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Svhutech_nckh4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Vietnamese science students working on an experiment in their university lab." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Svhutech_nckh4.jpg/220px-Svhutech_nckh4.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Svhutech_nckh4.jpg/330px-Svhutech_nckh4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Svhutech_nckh4.jpg/440px-Svhutech_nckh4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="533"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Svhutech_nckh4.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Vietnamese science students working on an <a href="/wiki/Experiment" title="Experiment">experiment</a> in their university lab.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Institute_for_Statistics" title="UNESCO Institute for Statistics">UNESCO Institute for Statistics</a>, Vietnam devoted 0.19% of its GDP to science research and development in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Media_Services2016_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Media_Services2016-312">[303]</a></sup> Between 2005 and 2014, the number of Vietnamese scientific publications recorded in Thomson Reuters' <a href="/wiki/Web_of_Science" title="Web of Science">Web of Science</a> increased at a rate well above the average for Southeast Asia, albeit from a modest starting point.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714-313">[304]</a></sup> Publications focus mainly on <a href="/wiki/Life_science" class="mw-redirect" title="Life science">life sciences</a> (22%), <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/physic" class="extiw" title="wikt:physic">physics</a> (13%) and <a href="/wiki/Engineering" title="Engineering">engineering</a> (13%), which is consistent with recent advances in the production of diagnostic equipment and shipbuilding.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714_313-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714-313">[304]</a></sup> Almost 77% of all papers published between 2008 and 2014 had at least one international co-author. The autonomy which Vietnamese research centres have enjoyed since the mid-1990s has enabled many of them to operate as quasi-private organisations, providing services such as consulting and technology development.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714_313-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714-313">[304]</a></sup> Some have 'spun off' from the larger institutions to form their own semi-private enterprises, fostering the transfer of public sector science and technology personnel to these semi-private establishments. One comparatively new university, the <a href="/wiki/T%C3%B4n_%C4%90%E1%BB%A9c_Th%E1%BA%AFng_University" title="Tôn Đức Thắng University">Tôn Đức Thắng University</a> which was built in 1997, has already set up 13 centres for technology transfer and services that together produce 15% of university revenue. Many of these research centres serve as valuable intermediaries bridging public research institutions, universities, and firms.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714_313-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Publishing713–714-313">[304]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Vietnam" title="Tourism in Vietnam">Tourism in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an,_vue_de_nuit.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of Hội An, a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a major tourist destination" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg/220px-Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg/330px-Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg/440px-Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an%2C_vue_de_nuit.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Pont-pagode_%22japonais%22_de_Hoi-an,_vue_de_nuit.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="Hội An">Hội An</a>, a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Educational,_Scientific_and_Cultural_Organization" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Southeast_Asia" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Southeast Asia">World Heritage Site</a> is a major tourist destination.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Tourism is an important element of economic activity in the country, contributing 7.5% of the gross domestic product. Vietnam welcomed over 12.9&nbsp;million visitors in 2017, an increase of 29.1% over the previous year, making it one of the fastest growing tourist destinations in recent years. The vast majority of visitors in 2017, 9.7&nbsp;million, came from <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>. China (4&nbsp;million), South Korea (2.6&nbsp;million) and Japan (798,119) made up half of all international arrivals in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018-314">[305]</a></sup> Vietnam also attracts large numbers of visitors from <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> with almost 1.9&nbsp;million visitors in 2017. <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> (574,164) and the United Kingdom (283,537), followed closely by France (255,396) and <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> (199,872) were the largest source of international arrivals from Europe. Other significant international arrivals by nationality include the United States (614,117) and <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> (370,438).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2018-314">[305]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The most visited destinations in Vietnam are Ho Chi Minh City with 5.8&nbsp;million international arrivals, followed by Hanoi with 4.6&nbsp;million and <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long" title="Hạ Long">Hạ Long</a>, including Hạ Long Bay with 4.4&nbsp;million arrivals. All three are ranked in the top 100 most visited cities in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuy2018_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuy2018-315">[306]</a></sup> Vietnam is home to eight <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. In 2018, <i><a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">Travel + Leisure</a></i> ranked <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="Hội An">Hội An</a> as one of the world's top 15 best destinations to visit.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETerzian2018_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETerzian2018-316">[307]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Infrastructure">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Transport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Vietnam" title="Transport in Vietnam">Transport in Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Vietnam" title="Rail transport in Vietnam">Rail transport in Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Vietnam" title="List of airports in Vietnam">List of airports in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Much of Vietnam's modern transportation network can trace its roots to the French colonial era when it was used to facilitate the transportation of <a href="/wiki/Raw_material" title="Raw material">raw materials</a> to its main ports. It was extensively expanded and modernised following the partition of Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrook20147_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrook20147-317">[308]</a></sup> Vietnam's road system includes national roads administered at the central level, provincial roads managed at the provincial level, district roads managed at the district level, urban roads managed by cities and towns and commune roads managed at the commune level.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010-318">[309]</a></sup> In 2010, Vietnam's road system had a total length of about 188,744 kilometres (117,280&nbsp;mi) of which 93,535 kilometres (58,120&nbsp;mi) are <a href="/wiki/Asphalt" title="Asphalt">asphalt</a> roads comprising national, provincial and district roads.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010_318-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010-318">[309]</a></sup> The length of the national road system is about 15,370 kilometres (9,550&nbsp;mi) with 15,085 kilometres (9,373&nbsp;mi) of its length paved. The provincial road system has around 27,976 kilometres (17,383&nbsp;mi) of paved roads while 50,474 kilometres (31,363&nbsp;mi) district roads are paved.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010_318-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2010-318">[309]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh,_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of Ho Chi Minh City's North-South Expressway" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG/220px-C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG/330px-C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG/440px-C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh%2C_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2456" data-file-height="1632"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:C%E1%BA%A7u_Long_Th%C3%A0nh,_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_cao_t%E1%BB%91c_TP.HCM_-_Long_Th%C3%A0nh_-_D%E1%BA%A7u_Gi%C3%A2y.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_%E2%80%93_Long_Thanh_%E2%80%93_Dau_Giay_Expressway" class="mw-redirect" title="Ho Chi Minh City – Long Thanh – Dau Giay Expressway">HCMC–LT–DG</a> section of the <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Expressway_(Vietnam)" class="mw-redirect" title="North–South Expressway (Vietnam)">North–South Expressway</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of Tan Son Nhat International Airport" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg/220px-Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg/330px-Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg/440px-Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1800" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tan_Son_Nhat_International_Airport" title="Tan Son Nhat International Airport">Tan Son Nhat International Airport</a> is the busiest airport in the country.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Bicycle" title="Bicycle">Bicycles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle" title="Motorcycle">motorcycles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Motor_scooter" class="mw-redirect" title="Motor scooter">motor scooters</a> remain the most popular forms of road transport in the country, a legacy of the French, though the number of privately owned <a href="/wiki/Car" title="Car">cars</a> has been increasing in recent years.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuu_DucMai_HoaThien_HuongNgoc_Bao20132080_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuu_DucMai_HoaThien_HuongNgoc_Bao20132080-319">[310]</a></sup> Public buses operated by private companies are the main mode of long-distance travel for much of the population. <a href="/wiki/Traffic_collision" title="Traffic collision">Road accidents</a> remain the major safety issue of Vietnamese transportation with an average of 30 people losing their lives daily.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2011_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2011-320">[311]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">Traffic congestion</a> is a growing problem in both Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City especially with the growth of individual car ownership.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELinh_LeAnh_Trinh2016_321-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELinh_LeAnh_Trinh2016-321">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESohrBrockfeldSauerländerMelde2016220_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESohrBrockfeldSauerländerMelde2016220-322">[313]</a></sup> Vietnam's primary cross-country rail service is the <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Railway_(Vietnam)" class="mw-redirect" title="North–South Railway (Vietnam)">Reunification Express</a> from Ho Chi Minh City to Hanoi, a distance of nearly 1,726 kilometres (1,072&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChin2018_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChin2018-323">[314]</a></sup> From Hanoi, railway lines branch out to the northeast, north, and west; the eastbound line runs from Hanoi to Hạ Long Bay, the northbound line from Hanoi to <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_Nguy%C3%AAn" title="Thái Nguyên">Thái Nguyên</a>, and the northeast line from Hanoi to Lào Cai. In 2009, Vietnam and Japan signed a deal to build a <a href="/wiki/North%E2%80%93South_Express_Railway_(Vietnam)" class="mw-redirect" title="North–South Express Railway (Vietnam)">high-speed railway</a>—<a href="/wiki/Shinkansen" title="Shinkansen">shinkansen</a> (bullet train)—using Japanese technology.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Japan_Times''2009_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Japan_Times''2009-324">[315]</a></sup> Vietnamese engineers were sent to Japan to receive training in the operation and maintenance of high-speed trains.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam+2008_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam+2008-325">[316]</a></sup> The planned railway will be a 1,545 kilometres (960&nbsp;mi)-long express route serving a total of 23 stations, including Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, with 70% of its route running on bridges and through tunnels.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Nation''2018_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Nation''2018-326">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2018b_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2018b-327">[318]</a></sup> The trains will travel at a maximum speed of 350 kilometres (220&nbsp;mi) per hour.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2018b_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2018b-327">[318]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESouth_East_Asia_Iron_and_Steel_Institute2009_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESouth_East_Asia_Iron_and_Steel_Institute2009-328">[319]</a></sup> Plans for the high-speed rail line, however, have been postponed after the Vietnamese government decided to prioritise the development of both the <a href="/wiki/Hanoi_Metro" title="Hanoi Metro">Hanoi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Metro" title="Ho Chi Minh City Metro">Ho Chi Minh City</a> metros and expand road networks instead.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChin2018_323-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChin2018-323">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChi2017_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChi2017-329">[320]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETatarski2017_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETatarski2017-330">[321]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal,_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Photograph if a crane at the Port of Hai Phong" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG/220px-Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG/330px-Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG/440px-Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal%2C_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ch%C3%B9a_V%E1%BA%BD_Terminal,_Port_of_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The port of <a href="/wiki/Hai_Phong" class="mw-redirect" title="Hai Phong">Hai Phong</a> is one of the largest and busiest container ports in Vietnam.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnam operates 20 major civil airports, including three international gateways: <a href="/wiki/Noi_Bai" class="mw-redirect" title="Noi Bai">Noi Bai</a> in Hanoi, <a href="/wiki/Da_Nang_International_Airport" title="Da Nang International Airport">Da Nang International Airport</a> in Đà Nẵng and <a href="/wiki/Tan_Son_Nhat" class="mw-redirect" title="Tan Son Nhat">Tan Son Nhat</a> in Ho Chi Minh City. Tan Son Nhat is the nation's largest airport handling the majority of international passenger traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoang20161_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoang20161-331">[322]</a></sup> According to a state-approved plan, Vietnam will have another seven international airports by 2025, including <a href="/wiki/Vinh_International_Airport" title="Vinh International Airport">Vinh International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phu_Bai_International_Airport" title="Phu Bai International Airport">Phu Bai International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cam_Ranh_International_Airport" title="Cam Ranh International Airport">Cam Ranh International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phu_Quoc_International_Airport" title="Phu Quoc International Airport">Phu Quoc International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cat_Bi_International_Airport" title="Cat Bi International Airport">Cat Bi International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Can_Tho_International_Airport" title="Can Tho International Airport">Can Tho International Airport</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Long_Thanh_International_Airport" title="Long Thanh International Airport">Long Thanh International Airport</a>. The planned Long Thanh International Airport will have an annual service capacity of 100&nbsp;million passengers once it becomes fully operational in 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Investment_Review''2018_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Investment_Review''2018-332">[323]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Airlines" title="Vietnam Airlines">Vietnam Airlines</a>, the state-owned national airline, maintains a fleet of 86 passenger aircraft and aims to operate 170 by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaGiangDenslow2012_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaGiangDenslow2012-333">[324]</a></sup> Several private airlines also operate in Vietnam, including <a href="/wiki/Air_Mekong" title="Air Mekong">Air Mekong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bamboo_Airways" title="Bamboo Airways">Bamboo Airways</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jetstar_Pacific_Airlines" class="mw-redirect" title="Jetstar Pacific Airlines">Jetstar Pacific Airlines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Air_Service_Company" class="mw-redirect" title="Vietnam Air Service Company">VASCO</a> and <a href="/wiki/VietJet_Air" title="VietJet Air">VietJet Air</a>. As a coastal country, Vietnam has many major sea ports, including <a href="/wiki/Cam_Ranh" title="Cam Ranh">Cam Ranh</a>, Đà Nẵng, <a href="/wiki/Haiphong" title="Haiphong">Hải Phòng</a>, Ho Chi Minh City, <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long" title="Hạ Long">Hạ Long</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qui_Nh%C6%A1n" title="Qui Nhơn">Qui Nhơn</a>, <a href="/wiki/V%C5%A9ng_T%C3%A0u" title="Vũng Tàu">Vũng Tàu</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BB%ADa_L%C3%B2" title="Cửa Lò">Cửa Lò</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nha_Trang" title="Nha Trang">Nha Trang</a>. Further inland, the country's extensive network of rivers plays a key role in rural transportation with over 47,130 kilometres (29,290&nbsp;mi) of navigable <a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterways</a> carrying ferries, barges and <a href="/wiki/Water_taxi" title="Water taxi">water taxis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2018_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2018-334">[325]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Energy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Vietnam" title="Energy in Vietnam">Energy in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_power_stations_in_Vietnam" title="List of power stations in Vietnam">List of power stations in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of the Son La Dam" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG/220px-S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG/330px-S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG/440px-S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1728"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:S%C6%A1n_La_Dam.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_La_Dam" title="Sơn La Dam">Sơn La Dam</a> in northern Vietnam, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_hydroelectric_power_stations" title="List of largest hydroelectric power stations">largest hydroelectric dam</a> in Southeast Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Intellasia''2010_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Intellasia''2010-335">[326]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnam's energy sector is dominated largely by the nationwide <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Electricity" title="Vietnam Electricity">Vietnam Electricity</a> Group (EVN). As of 2017, EVN made up about 61.4% of the country's power generation system with a total power capacity of 25,884 <a href="/wiki/Megawatt" class="mw-redirect" title="Megawatt">MW</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201710_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201710-336">[327]</a></sup> Other energy sources are <a href="/wiki/PetroVietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="PetroVietnam">PetroVietnam</a> (4,435 MW), <a href="/wiki/Vinacomin" title="Vinacomin">Vinacomin</a> (1,785 MW) and 10,031 MW from <a href="/wiki/Build%E2%80%93operate%E2%80%93transfer" title="Build–operate–transfer">build–operate–transfer</a> (BOT) investors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712-337">[328]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most of Vietnam's power is generated by either <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a> or <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_power_station" title="Fossil fuel power station">fossil fuel power</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oil" title="Oil">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Diesel_fuel" title="Diesel fuel">diesel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Small_hydropower" class="mw-redirect" title="Small hydropower">small hydropower</a> and renewable energy supplies the remainder.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712_337-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElectricity_of_Vietnam201712-337">[328]</a></sup> The Vietnamese government had planned to develop a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactor</a> as the path to establish <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_energy_in_Vietnam" title="Nuclear energy in Vietnam">another source for electricity</a> from <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a>. The plan was abandoned in late 2016 when a majority of the National Assembly voted to oppose the project due to widespread public concern over <a href="/wiki/Radioactive_contamination" title="Radioactive contamination">radioactive contamination</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyenBinh_MinhPhamBurmistrova2016_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyenBinh_MinhPhamBurmistrova2016-338">[329]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The household gas sector in Vietnam is dominated by PetroVietnam, which controls nearly 70% of the country's domestic market for <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas" title="Liquefied petroleum gas">liquefied petroleum gas</a> (LPG).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Nikkei_Asian_Review''_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Nikkei_Asian_Review''-339">[330]</a></sup> Since 2011, the company also operates five renewable energy power plants including the Nhơn Trạch 2 Thermal Power Plant (750 MW), Phú Quý Wind Power Plant (6 MW), Hủa Na Hydro-power Plant (180 MW), Dakdrinh Hydro-power Plant (125 MW) and Vũng Áng 1 Thermal Power Plant (1,200 MW).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201670_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201670-340">[331]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to statistics from <a href="/wiki/British_Petroleum" class="mw-redirect" title="British Petroleum">British Petroleum</a> (BP), Vietnam is listed among the 52 countries that have <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">proven crude oil reserves</a>. In 2015 the reserve was approximately 4.4&nbsp;billion barrels ranking Vietnam first place in Southeast Asia, while the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_proven_reserves" title="List of countries by natural gas proven reserves">proven gas reserves</a> were about 0.6&nbsp;trillion cubic meters (tcm) and ranking it third in Southeast Asia after <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201664_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEViet_TrungQuoc_VietVan_Chat201664-341">[332]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunication">Telecommunication</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Telecommunication">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Vietnam" title="Telecommunications in Vietnam">Telecommunications in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Telecommunications services in Vietnam are wholly provided by the Vietnam Post and Telecommunications General Corporation (now the <a href="/wiki/VNPT" class="mw-redirect" title="VNPT">VNPT</a> Group) which is a <a href="/wiki/State-owned" class="mw-redirect" title="State-owned">state-owned</a> company.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPham20156_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPham20156-342">[333]</a></sup> The VNPT retained its monopoly until 1986. The telecom sector was reformed in 1995 when the Vietnamese government began to implement a competitive policy with the creation of two domestic telecommunication companies, the Military Electronic and Telecommunication Company (<a href="/wiki/Viettel" title="Viettel">Viettel</a>, which is wholly owned by the Vietnamese Ministry of Defence) and the Saigon Post and Telecommunication Company (SPT or SaigonPostel), with 18% of it owned by VNPT.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPham20156_342-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPham20156-342">[333]</a></sup> VNPT's monopoly was finally ended by the government in 2003 with the issuance of a decree.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPham20157_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPham20157-343">[334]</a></sup> By 2012, the top three telecom operators in Vietnam were Viettel, <a href="/wiki/Vinaphone" title="Vinaphone">Vinaphone</a> and <a href="/wiki/MobiFone" title="MobiFone">MobiFone</a>. The remaining companies included: <a href="/wiki/EVNTelecom" title="EVNTelecom">EVNTelecom</a>, Vietnammobile and <a href="/wiki/S-Fone" title="S-Fone">S-Fone</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2012_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2012-344">[335]</a></sup> With the shift towards a more <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market-orientated economy</a>, Vietnam's telecommunications market is continuously being reformed to attract foreign investment, which includes the supply of services and the establishment of nationwide telecom infrastructure.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2017_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2017-345">[336]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Water supply and sanitation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Vietnam" title="Water supply and sanitation in Vietnam">Water supply and sanitation in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Stream flowing down a hill with a bridge crossing it" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg/220px-Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg/330px-Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg/440px-Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1536" data-file-height="2048"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Village_vietnam_sapa_bridge.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>In rural areas of Vietnam, <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">piped water systems</a> are operated by a wide variety of institutions including a national organisation, people committees (local government), community groups, co-operatives and private companies.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnam has 2,360 rivers with an average annual discharge of 310&nbsp;billion <a href="/wiki/Cubic_metre" title="Cubic metre">m³</a>. The rainy season accounts for 70% of the year's discharge.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20171_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20171-346">[337]</a></sup> Most of the country's urban <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">water supply</a> systems have been developed without proper management within the last 10 years. Based on a 2008 survey by the Vietnam Water Supply and Sewerage Association (VWSA), existing water production capacity exceeded demand, but service coverage is still sparse. Most of the clean water supply infrastructure is not widely developed. It is only available to a small proportion of the population with about one third of 727 district towns having some form of piped water supply.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172-347">[338]</a></sup> There is also concern over the safety of existing water resources for urban and rural water supply systems. Most industrial factories release their untreated <a href="/wiki/Wastewater" title="Wastewater">wastewater</a> directly into the water sources. Where the government does not take measures to address the issue, most domestic wastewater is discharged, untreated, back into the environment and pollutes the <a href="/wiki/Surface_water" title="Surface water">surface water</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172_347-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade20172-347">[338]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In recent years, there have been some efforts and collaboration between local and foreign universities to develop access to safe water in the country by introducing <a href="/wiki/Water_filter" title="Water filter">water filtration systems</a>. There is a growing concern among local populations over the serious public health issues associated with water contamination caused by pollution as well as the <a href="/wiki/Arsenic_contamination_of_groundwater" title="Arsenic contamination of groundwater">high levels of arsenic</a> in <a href="/wiki/Groundwater" title="Groundwater">groundwater</a> sources.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUniversity_of_Technology_Sydney2018_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUniversity_of_Technology_Sydney2018-348">[339]</a></sup> The government of <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> has been providing aid focusing its investments mainly on water-related sectors including <a href="/wiki/Water_treatment" title="Water treatment">water treatment</a> projects.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2016_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2016-349">[340]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2018_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_the_Netherlands2018-350">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2018_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2018-351">[342]</a></sup> Regarding <a href="/wiki/Sanitation" title="Sanitation">sanitation</a>, 78% of Vietnam's population has access to <a href="/wiki/Improved_sanitation" title="Improved sanitation">"improved" sanitation</a>—94% of the urban population and 70% of the rural population. However, there are still about 21&nbsp;million people in the country lacking access to "improved" sanitation according to a survey conducted in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNICEF2015_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNICEF2015-352">[343]</a></sup> In 2018, the construction ministry said the country's water supply, and drainage industry had been applying hi-tech methods and <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> (IT) to sanitation issues but faced problems like limited funding, climate change, and pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018c_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018c-353">[344]</a></sup> The health ministry has also announced that water inspection units will be established nationwide beginning in June 2019. Inspections are to be conducted without notice since there have been many cases involving health issues caused by poor or polluted water supplies as well unhygienic conditions reported every year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018d_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018d-354">[345]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Health">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Vietnam" title="Health in Vietnam">Health in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <p>By 2015, 97% of the population had access to improved water sources.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2016_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIndex_Mundi2016-355">[346]</a></sup> In 2016, Vietnam's national <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> stood at 80.9 years for women and 71.5 for men, and the <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate was 17 per 1,000 live births.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016a_356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016a-356">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016b_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2016b-357">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2017_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2017-358">[349]</a></sup> Despite these improvements, <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> is still common in rural provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003_167-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003-167">[160]</a></sup> Since the partition, North Vietnam has established a public health system that has reached down to the <a href="/wiki/Hamlet_(place)" title="Hamlet (place)">hamlet</a> level.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Harvard_Crimson''1972_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Harvard_Crimson''1972-359">[350]</a></sup> After the national reunification in 1975, a nationwide health service was established.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003_167-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003-167">[160]</a></sup> In the late 1980s, the quality of healthcare declined to some degree as a result of budgetary constraints, a shift of responsibility to the provinces and the introduction of charges.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECuong_LeKuboFujinoMinh_Pham201023-285">[276]</a></sup> Inadequate funding has also contributed to a shortage of <a href="/wiki/Nurses" class="mw-redirect" title="Nurses">nurses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midwives" class="mw-redirect" title="Midwives">midwives</a> and hospital beds; in 2000, Vietnam had only 24.7 hospital beds per 10,000 people before declining to 23.7 in 2005 as stated in the annual report of <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Vietnam)" title="Ministry of Health (Vietnam)">Vietnamese Health Ministry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrung_Chien200665_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrung_Chien200665-360">[351]</a></sup> The controversial use of herbicides as a chemical weapon by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">US military</a> during the war left tangible, long-term <a href="/wiki/Effects_of_Agent_Orange_on_the_Vietnamese_people" title="Effects of Agent Orange on the Vietnamese people">impacts upon the Vietnamese people</a> that persist in the country today.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2005_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2005-361">[352]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaberman2014_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaberman2014-362">[353]</a></sup> For instance, it led to three million Vietnamese people suffering health problems, one million birth defects caused directly by exposure to the chemical and 24% of Vietnam's land being defoliated.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGustafsson2010125_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGustafsson2010125-363">[354]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the early 2000s, Vietnam has made significant progress in combating <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>. The malaria mortality rate fell to about five percent of its 1990s equivalent by 2005 after the country introduced improved antimalarial drugs and treatment.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Namde_VriesVan_ToiNagelkerke2005_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Namde_VriesVan_ToiNagelkerke2005-364">[355]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">Tuberculosis</a> (TB) cases, however, are on the rise. TB has become the second most infectious disease in the country after <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_disease" title="Respiratory disease">respiratory-related illness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrinhNguyenDoNguyen2016_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrinhNguyenDoNguyen2016-365">[356]</a></sup> With an intensified vaccination program, better hygiene and foreign assistance, Vietnam hopes to reduce sharply the number of TB cases and new TB infections.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016-366">[357]</a></sup> In 2004, government subsidies covering about 15% of health care expenses.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELiebermanWagstaff200940_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELiebermanWagstaff200940-367">[358]</a></sup> That year, the United States announced Vietnam would be one of 15 nations to receive funding as part of its global AIDS relief plan.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEManyin20054_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEManyin20054-368">[359]</a></sup> By the following year, Vietnam had diagnosed 101,291 <a href="/wiki/Human_immunodeficiency_virus" class="mw-redirect" title="Human immunodeficiency virus">human immunodeficiency virus</a> (HIV) cases, of which 16,528 progressed to <a href="/wiki/Acquired_immune_deficiency_syndrome" class="mw-redirect" title="Acquired immune deficiency syndrome">acquired immune deficiency syndrome</a> (AIDS); 9,554 have died.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Women's_Union2005_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Women's_Union2005-369">[360]</a></sup> The actual number of HIV-positive individuals is estimated to be much higher. On average between 40 and 50 new infections are reported daily in the country. In 2007, 0.4% of the population was estimated to be infected with HIV and the figure has remained stable since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2018a_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2018a-370">[361]</a></sup> More global aid is being delivered through <a href="/wiki/The_Global_Fund_to_Fight_AIDS,_Tuberculosis_and_Malaria" title="The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria">The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria</a> to fight the spread of the disease in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016_366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNeil_Jr.2016-366">[357]</a></sup> In September 2018, the Hanoi People's Committee urged the citizens of the country to stop eating <a href="/wiki/Dog_meat" title="Dog meat">dog</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cat_meat" title="Cat meat">cat meat</a> as it can cause diseases like <a href="/wiki/Rabies" title="Rabies">rabies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leptospirosis" title="Leptospirosis">leptospirosis</a>. More than 1,000 stores in the capital city of Hanoi were found to be selling both meats.
