The decision prompted positive comments among Vietnamese on <a href="/wiki/Social_media" title="Social media">social media</a>, though some noted that the consumption of dog meat will remain an ingrained habit among many people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2018_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2018-371">[362]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Education">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Vietnam" title="Education in Vietnam">Education in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of the Indochina Medical College building" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg/220px-VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg/330px-VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg/440px-VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1506" data-file-height="1004"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:VNU_lethanhtong_900x600.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Indochina_Medical_College" class="mw-redirect" title="Indochina Medical College">Indochina Medical College</a> in Hanoi, the first modern university in Vietnam
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnam has an extensive state-controlled network of schools, colleges, and universities and a growing number of privately run and partially privatised institutions. General education in Vietnam is divided into five categories: <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">kindergarten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elementary_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Elementary school">elementary schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">middle schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/High_school" class="mw-redirect" title="High school">high schools</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Universities" class="mw-redirect" title="Universities">universities</a>. A large number of public schools have been constructed across the country to raise the national <a href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a>, which stood at 90% in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNICEF_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNICEF-372">[363]</a></sup> Most universities are located in major cities of Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City with the country's education system continuously undergoing a series of reforms by the government. <a href="/wiki/Basic_education" title="Basic education">Basic education</a> in the country is relatively free for the poor although some families may still have trouble paying tuition fees for their children without some form of public or private assistance.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHa_Trân2014_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHa_Trân2014-373">[364]</a></sup> Regardless, Vietnam's school enrolment is among the highest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2013_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2013-374">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2015_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2015-375">[366]</a></sup> The number of colleges and universities increased dramatically in the 2000s from 178 in 2000 to 299 in 2005. In higher education, the government provides subsidised loans for students through the national bank, although there are deep concerns about access to the loans as well the burden on students to repay them.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPham2012_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPham2012-376">[367]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChapmanLiu2013_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChapmanLiu2013-377">[368]</a></sup>Since 1995, enrolment in higher education has grown tenfold to over 2.2&nbsp;million with 84,000 lecturers and 419 institutions of higher education.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEde_MoraWood201455_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEde_MoraWood201455-378">[369]</a></sup> A number of foreign universities operate private campuses in Vietnam, including <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a> (USA) and the <a href="/wiki/RMIT_University_Vietnam" title="RMIT University Vietnam">Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology</a> (Australia). The government's strong commitment to education has fostered significant growth but still need to be sustained to retain academics. In 2018, a decree on university autonomy allowing them to operate independently without ministerial control is in its final stages of approval. The government will continue investing in education especially for the poor to have access to basic education.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2016b_379-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2016b-379">[370]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Demographics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Vietnam" title="Demographics of Vietnam">Demographics of Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_people" title="Vietnamese people">Vietnamese people</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic groups in Vietnam">Ethnic groups in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Six women in costume holding fans in each hand perform a dance in front of an audience" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg/220px-Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg/330px-Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg/440px-Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg 2x" data-file-width="760" data-file-height="505"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_cultural_dance.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Folk_dance" title="Folk dance">Cultural dance</a> performed by one of <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_Vietnam" title="List of ethnic groups in Vietnam">54 recognised Vietnamese ethnic groups</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the population of Vietnam stands at approximately 95.5 million people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs_380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs-380">[371]</a></sup> The population had grown significantly from the 1979 census, which showed the total population of reunified Vietnam to be 52.7&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFraser1980_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFraser1980-381">[372]</a></sup> According to the 2019 census, the country's population was 96,208,984.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2019_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2019-5">[3]</a></sup> Based on the 2019 census, 65.6% of the Vietnamese population are living in rural areas while only 34.4% live in urban areas. The average growth rate of the urban population has recently increased which is attributed mainly to migration and rapid urbanisation.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2019_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2019-5">[3]</a></sup> The dominant <a href="/wiki/Viet_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Viet people">Viet</a> or Kinh ethnic group constitute 82,085,826 people or 85.32% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2019_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2019-5">[3]</a></sup> Most of their population is concentrated in the country's <a href="/wiki/Alluvial_fans" class="mw-redirect" title="Alluvial fans">alluvial deltas</a> and coastal plains. As a majority ethnic group, the Kinh possess significant political and economic influence over the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones199821_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones199821-382">[373]</a></sup> Despite this, Vietnam is also home to 54 other ethnic minority groups, including the <a href="/wiki/Hmong_people" title="Hmong people">Hmong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yao_people" title="Yao people">Dao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tay_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tay people">Tày</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thai_people" title="Thai people">Thai</a> and <a href="/wiki/N%C3%B9ng_people" title="Nùng people">Nùng</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECanada_Ministry_of_Citizenship_and_Immigration20131_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECanada_Ministry_of_Citizenship_and_Immigration20131-383">[374]</a></sup> Many ethnic minorities such as the <a href="/wiki/Muong_people" title="Muong people">Muong</a>, who are closely related to the Kinh, dwell in the highlands which cover two-thirds of Vietnam's territory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(I)_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(I)-384">[375]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The labor force aged 15 and over in the country in 2019 was more than 55 million persons.<sup id="cite_ref-vn_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vn-385">[376]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[377]</a></sup> The number of employed population aged 15 and over in 2019 was 54.7 million persons, including nearly 19 million persons working in the agriculture, forestry and fishing sector, accounting for 34.5% of the total labor (decreasing by 3.1 percentage points against the previous year); more than 16 million persons working in the industry and construction sector, accounting for 30.2% (rising by 2.9 percentage points); and around 19.5 million persons working in the service sector, making up 35.3% (increasing by 0.2 percentage points).<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[378]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[379]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[380]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The whole country’s general unemployment rate in 2019 was 1.98% (it was 2.00% in the first quarter; 1.98% in the second quarter; 1.99% in the third quarter; 1.98% in the fourth quarter), of which it was 2.93% for urban areas; 1.51% for rural areas.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[381]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2019, the Human Development Index (HDI) reached a good level of 0.704.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[382]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2020, until May 29, the total value of gifts had been given to social policy beneficiaries, national devotees and social protection beneficiaries were about 9.4 trillion VND. <sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[383]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[384]</a></sup> Besides, more than 24 million health insurance cards, free health care books/cards were donated to policy beneficiaries in the whole country. As of September 15th, 2020, more than 12.5 trillion VND was disbursed nationwide to support people in difficulty due to the Covid-19 epidemic. <sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The national income per capita per month in 2019 was estimated at approximately 4.3 million VND, growing by 10.9% over that in 2018, of which the urban area achieved 6.02 million VND, an increase of 7.1%; the rural area gained 3.4 million VND, up 13.8%. The income per capita per month at current prices in 2019 of the regions in the country increased in comparison to that in 2018, of which the North Central and Central coastal areas gained the highest income growth rate with 10.5%; the Red River Delta jumped up 8.7%; the South East and Mekong River Delta both rose by 8.4%; the Northern midlands and mountain areas reached an expansion of 7.7% and the increase of 6.9% was placed in the Central Highlands. However, there was income disparity amongst regions and income quintile groups. The South East recorded the highest rate of income per capita (6.28 million VND), which was 2.4 times higher than the lowest rate in the Northern midlands and mountain areas (2.64 million VND). The income per capita per month of the quintile group of 20% of the population with the highest income achieved 10.1 million VND (increasing by 8.4% over that in 2018), which was 10.2 times higher than that of the quintile group of 20% of the population with the lowest income with 988 thousand VND (rising by 6%). The income disparity and rich-poor gap amongst the population were reflected in the inequality ratio in income distribution (GINI coefficient) . In 2019, the national GINI coefficient was 0.423; of which the rural area (0.415) revealed more disparities than the urban area (0.373). The income disparity and rich-poor gap amongst the population witnessed an improvement that was a decrease from 0.425 in 2018 to 0.423 in 2019, of which this gap remained unchanged in the urban areas; the gap in the rural areas increased from 0.408 in 2018 to 0.415 in 2019. <sup id="cite_ref-vn_385-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vn-385">[376]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The national rate of poverty households identified by multi-dimensional poverty standards was estimated at 5.7% in 2019, down 1.2 percentage points against 2018, of which the urban area was 1.2%, reducing by 0.3 percentage points and the rural area was 8%, decreasing by 1.6 percentage points. Amongst regions, the Northern midlands and mountain areas recorded the highest rate of poverty households identified by multi-dimensional poverty standards (16.4%); the lowest rate was placed in the South East (0.5%).<sup id="cite_ref-vn_385-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vn-385">[376]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other uplanders in the north migrated from southern China between the 1300s and 1800s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316_395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316-395">[386]</a></sup> Since the partition of Vietnam, the population of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> was almost exclusively <a href="/wiki/Degar" class="mw-redirect" title="Degar">Degar</a> (including over 40 tribal groups); however, the South Vietnamese government at the time enacted a program of resettling Kinh in indigenous areas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre7_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre7-396">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontagnard_Human_Rights_Organisation_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontagnard_Human_Rights_Organisation-397">[388]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hoa_people" title="Hoa people">Hoa</a> (ethnic <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">Chinese</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Krom" title="Khmer Krom">Khmer Krom</a> people are mainly lowlanders.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones199821_382-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones199821-382">[373]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316_395-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316-395">[386]</a></sup> Throughout Vietnam's history, many Chinese people, largely from <a href="/wiki/South_China" title="South China">South China</a>, migrated to the country as administrators, merchants and even refugees.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531-398">[389]</a></sup> Since the reunification in 1976 an increase of communist policies nationwide resulted in the nationalisation and confiscation of property especially from the Hoa in the south and the wealthy in cities. This led many of them to leave Vietnam.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAmer1996_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmer1996-399">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFeinberg2016_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFeinberg2016-400">[391]</a></sup> Furthermore, with the deterioration of <a href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Sino-Vietnamese relations">Sino-Vietnamese relations</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War" title="Sino-Vietnamese War">border invasion</a> by Chinese government in 1979 many Vietnamese were wary of Chinese government's intentions. This indirectly caused more Hoa people in the north to leave the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531_398-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531-398">[389]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGough1986_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGough1986-401">[392]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Urbanisation">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Vietnam" title="List of cities in Vietnam">List of cities in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_(night).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Ho Chi Minh City's District 1 skyline photographed at night" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg/300px-Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg/450px-Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg/600px-Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3304" data-file-height="1815"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_(night).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/District_1,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="District 1, Ho Chi Minh City">District 1</a>, Ho Chi Minh City.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The number of people who live in urbanised areas in 2019 is 33,122,548 people (with the urbanisation rate at 34.4%).<sup id="cite_ref-Census2019_5-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2019-5">[3]</a></sup> Since 1986, Vietnam's urbanisation rates have surged rapidly after the Vietnamese government implemented the Đổi Mới economic program, changing the system into a socialist one and liberalising property rights. As a result, Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City (the two major cities in the Red River Delta and Southeast regions respectively) increased their share of the total urban population from 8.5% and 24.9% to 15.9% and 31% respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b117_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b117-402">[393]</a></sup> The Vietnamese government, through its <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Construction_(Vietnam)" title="Ministry of Construction (Vietnam)">construction ministry</a>, forecasts the country will have a 45% urbanisation rate by 2020 although it was confirmed to only be 34.4% according to the 2019 census.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2019_5-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2019-5">[3]</a></sup> Urbanisation is said to have a positive correlation with economic growth. Any country with higher urbanisation rates has a higher GDP growth rate.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2002_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2002-403">[394]</a></sup> Furthermore, the urbanisation movement in Vietnam is mainly between the rural areas and the country's Southeast region. Ho Chi Minh City has received a large number of migrants due mainly to better weather and economic opportunities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b102_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b102-404">[395]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:West_Hanoi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph showing the large number of high-rise buildings in west Hanoi" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/West_Hanoi.jpg/220px-West_Hanoi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="93" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/West_Hanoi.jpg/330px-West_Hanoi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/West_Hanoi.jpg/440px-West_Hanoi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="435"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:West_Hanoi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Urbanisation in west Hanoi
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A study also shows that rural-to-urban area migrants have a higher standard of living than both non-migrants in rural areas and non-migrants in urban areas. This results in changes to economic structures. In 1985, agriculture made up 37.2% of Vietnam's GDP; in 2008, that number had declined to 18.5%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-405">[396]</a></sup> In 1985, industry made up only 26.2% of Vietnam's GDP; by 2008, that number had increased to 43.2%. Urbanisation also helps to improve basic services which increase people's standards of living. Access to electricity grew from 14% of total households with electricity in 1993 to above 96% in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_405-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-405">[396]</a></sup> In terms of access to fresh water, data from 65 utility companies shows that only 12% of households in the area covered by them had access to the water network in 2002; by 2007, more than 70% of the population was connected. Though urbanisation has many benefits, it has some drawbacks since it creates more traffic, and air and water pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_405-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-405">[396]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Many Vietnamese use <a href="/wiki/Moped" title="Moped">mopeds</a> for transportation since they are relatively cheap and easy to operate. Their large numbers have been known to cause traffic congestion and air pollution in Vietnam. In the capital city alone, the number of mopeds increased from 0.5&nbsp;million in 2001 to 4.7&nbsp;million in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_405-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-405">[396]</a></sup> With rapid development, factories have sprung up which indirectly pollute the air and water. An example is the <a href="/wiki/2016_Vietnam_marine_life_disaster" title="2016 Vietnam marine life disaster">2016 Vietnam marine life disaster</a> caused by the <a href="/wiki/Formosa_Ha_Tinh_Steel" title="Formosa Ha Tinh Steel">Formosa Ha Tinh Steel</a> Company illegally discharging toxic industrial waste into the ocean. This killed many fish and destroyed marine habitats in Vietnamese waters resulting in major losses to the country's economy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETiezzi2016_406-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETiezzi2016-406">[397]</a></sup> The government is intervening and attempting solutions to decrease air pollution by decreasing the number of motorcycles while increasing public transportation. It has introduced more regulations for <a href="/wiki/Waste" title="Waste">waste</a> handling by factories. Although the authorities also have schedules for collecting different types of waste, waste disposal is another problem caused by urbanisation. The amount of solid waste generated in urban areas of Vietnam has increased by more than 200% from 2003 to 2008. Industrial solid waste accounted for 181% of that increase. One of the government's efforts includes attempting to promote campaigns that encourage locals to sort <a href="/wiki/Municipal_solid_waste" title="Municipal solid waste">household waste</a> since <a href="/wiki/Waste_sorting" title="Waste sorting">waste sorting</a> is still not practised by most of Vietnamese society.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrương201819_407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrương201819-407">[398]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

         <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a href="/wiki/File:Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0,_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i,_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng,_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image" title="Haiphong"><img alt="Haiphong" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0%2C_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i%2C_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng%2C_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg/120px-Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0%2C_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i%2C_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng%2C_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="68" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0%2C_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i%2C_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng%2C_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg/180px-Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0%2C_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i%2C_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng%2C_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0%2C_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i%2C_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng%2C_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg/240px-Tt._C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0%2C_C%C3%A1t_H%E1%BA%A3i%2C_H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng%2C_Vietnam_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5710" data-file-height="3213"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Haiphong" title="Haiphong">Haiphong</a><br><a href="/wiki/File:Can_tho.jpg" class="image" title="Cần Thơ"><img alt="Cần Thơ" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Can_tho.jpg/120px-Can_tho.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="90" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Can_tho.jpg/180px-Can_tho.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Can_tho.jpg/240px-Can_tho.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a><br><a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Th%C6%A1" title="Cần Thơ">Cần Thơ</a> </td>

         <td style="text-align:right;">311,000 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">6</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_N%E1%BA%B5ng" class="mw-redirect" title="Đà Nẵng">Đà Nẵng</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Vietnam" title="Municipalities of Vietnam">Municipality</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">1,080,700</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">16</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long" title="Hạ Long">Hạ Long</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_Ninh_Province" title="Quảng Ninh Province">Quảng Ninh</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">300,267 </td>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">7</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Nha_Trang" title="Nha Trang">Nha Trang</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Kh%C3%A1nh_H%C3%B2a_Province" title="Khánh Hòa Province">Khánh Hòa</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">792,397</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">17</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Long_Xuy%C3%AAn" title="Long Xuyên">Long Xuyên</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/An_Giang_Province" title="An Giang Province">An Giang</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">280,300 </td>
        </tr>

         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">8</td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Vinh" title="Vinh">Vinh</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Ngh%E1%BB%87_An_Province" title="Nghệ An Province">Nghệ An</a></td> 
         <td style="text-align:right;">490,000</td> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">18</td>

      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Religion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Vietnam" title="Religion in Vietnam">Religion in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px"> 
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black"> 
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:#fcf7f7"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 13262.66059596px; border-left-color:#FF6600"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FF6600"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FF6600"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 8376.1780133552px; border-left-color:#b3ff9e"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#b3ff9e"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#b3ff9e"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 2065.3343769455px; border-left-color:#fffa75"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#fffa75"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#fffa75"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 885.3816277942px; border-left-color:#87CEFA"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#87CEFA"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#87CEFA"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 564.5924559666px; border-left-color:#edb7e9"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#edb7e9"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#edb7e9"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 160.00859471855px; border-left-color:#ffdab0"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#ffdab0"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#ffdab0"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 86.171595130805px; border-left-color:#e3ffff"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#e3ffff"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#e3ffff"></div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <p>Religion in Vietnam (2019)<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-408">[399]</a></sup> </p> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#e3ffff; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_folk_religion" title="Vietnamese folk religion">Vietnamese folk religion</a> or no religion (86.32%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ffdab0; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhism</a> (4.79%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#edb7e9; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Vietnam" title="Catholic Church in Vietnam">Catholicism</a> (6.1%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#87CEFA; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Vietnam" title="Protestantism in Vietnam">Protestantism</a> (1.0%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#fffa75; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="Hòa Hảo">Hoahaoism</a> (1.02%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#b3ff9e; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> (0.58%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#FF6600; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Islam (0.07%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#fcf7f7; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Others (0.12%)
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Under Article 70 of the 1992 Constitution of Vietnam, all citizens enjoy <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of belief and religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992-409">[400]</a></sup> All religions are equal before the law and each <a href="/wiki/Place_of_worship" title="Place of worship">place of worship</a> is protected under Vietnamese state law. Religious beliefs cannot be misused to undermine state law and policies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992_409-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992-409">[400]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ordinance_of_Beliefs_and_Religion2004_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ordinance_of_Beliefs_and_Religion2004-410">[401]</a></sup> According to a 2007 survey 81% of Vietnamese people <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">did not believe in a god</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZuckerman200711_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZuckerman200711-411">[402]</a></sup> Based on government findings in 2009, the number of religious people increased by 932,000.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009a_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009a-412">[403]</a></sup> The official statistics, presented by the Vietnamese government to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_special_rapporteur" title="United Nations special rapporteur">United Nations special rapporteur</a> in 2014, indicate the overall number of followers of recognised religions is about 24&nbsp;million of a total population of almost 90&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_413-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-413">[404]</a></sup> According to the General Statistics Office of Vietnam in 2019, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhists</a> account for 4.79% of the total population, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Vietnam" title="Catholic Church in Vietnam">Catholics</a> 6.1%, <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Vietnam" title="Protestantism in Vietnam">Protestants</a> 1.0%, <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="Hòa Hảo">Hoahao Buddhists</a> 1.02%, and <a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> followers 0.58%.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_408-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-408">[399]</a></sup> Other religions includes <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Bahaʼís</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, representing less than 0.2% of the population. </p>
      <p>The majority of Vietnamese do not follow any organized religion, though many of them observe some form of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_folk_religion" title="Vietnamese folk religion">Vietnamese folk religion</a>. <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> as a system of social and ethical philosophy still has certain influences in modern Vietnam. <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na_Buddhism" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahāyāna Buddhism">Mahāyāna</a> is the dominant branch of Buddhism, while <a href="/wiki/Therav%C4%81da_Buddhism" class="mw-redirect" title="Theravāda Buddhism">Theravāda</a> is practised mostly by the Khmer minority. About 8 to 9% of the population is Christian—made up of Roman Catholics and Protestants. Catholicism was introduced to Vietnam in the 16th century and was firmly established by <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuits</a> missionaries (mainly <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italian</a>) in the 17th centuries from nearby <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Portuguese Macau</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran2018_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran2018-72">[66]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French</a> missionaries (from the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Foreign_Missions_Society" title="Paris Foreign Missions Society">Paris Foreign Missions Society</a>) together with <a href="/wiki/Spaniards" title="Spaniards">Spanish</a> missionaries (from the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominican Order</a> of the neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a>) actively sought converts in the 18th, 19th, and first half of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200234_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200234-414">[405]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201242,_72_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201242,_72-415">[406]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELamport2018898_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELamport2018898-416">[407]</a></sup> A significant number of Vietnamese people, especially in the South, are also adherents of two indigenous religions of syncretic <a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> and quasi-Buddhist <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="Hòa Hảo">Hoahaoism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo2002168_417-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo2002168-417">[408]</a></sup> Protestantism was only recently spread by American and Canadian missionaries in the 20th century;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_418-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-418">[409]</a></sup> the largest Protestant denomination is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelical_Church_of_Vietnam_%E2%80%93_South&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evangelical Church of Vietnam – South (page does not exist)">Evangelical Church of Vietnam</a>. Around 770,000 of the country's Protestants are members of ethnic minorities,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_418-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-418">[409]</a></sup> particularly the highland <a href="/wiki/Montagnard_(Vietnam)" title="Montagnard (Vietnam)">Montagnards</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre5,_7_419-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre5,_7-419">[410]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hmong_people" title="Hmong people">Hmong people</a>. Although it is one of the country's minority religions, Protestantism is the <a href="/wiki/Fastest-growing_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Fastest-growing religion">fastest-growing religion</a> in Vietnam, expanding at a rate of 600% in recent decades.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_418-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-418">[409]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2005_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2005-420">[411]</a></sup> Several other minority faiths exist in Vietnam, these include: Bani, <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslim" title="Non-denominational Muslim">non-denominational</a> sections of Islam which is practised primarily among the ethnic <a href="/wiki/Cham_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Cham people">Cham</a> minority.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201135_421-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201135-421">[412]</a></sup> There are also a few Kinh adherents of Islam, other minority adherents of Baha'i, as well as <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Southeast_Asia#Vietnam" title="Hinduism in Southeast Asia">Hindus among the Cham</a>'s.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevinsonChristensen200289_422-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevinsonChristensen200289-422">[413]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200948_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200948-423">[414]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Languages">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_language" title="National language">national language</a> of the country is <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> (<i>tiếng Việt</i>), a tonal <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic language</a> (Mon–Khmer), which is spoken by the majority of the population. In its early history, Vietnamese writing used <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a> (<i>chữ Hán</i>) before a different meaning set of Chinese characters known as <i><a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_N%C3%B4m" title="Chữ Nôm">chữ Nôm</a></i> developed between the 7th–13th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292-424">[415]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoy2013340_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoy2013340-425">[416]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDinh_Tham201867_426-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDinh_Tham201867-426">[417]</a></sup> The folk epic <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text"><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Kieu" title="The Tale of Kieu">Truyện Kiều</a></i> (<i>The Tale of Kieu</i>, originally known as <i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text">Đoạn trường tân thanh</i>) by <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Du" title="Nguyễn Du">Nguyễn Du</a> was written in <i>chữ Nôm</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOzolinš2016130_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOzolinš2016130-427">[418]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_alphabet" title="Vietnamese alphabet">Chữ Quốc ngữ</a></i>, the Romanised Vietnamese alphabet, was developed in the 17th century by <a href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> missionaries such as <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Pina" title="Francisco de Pina">Francisco de Pina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_de_Rhodes" title="Alexandre de Rhodes">Alexandre de Rhodes</a> by using the alphabets of the <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance languages</a>, particularly the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_alphabet" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese alphabet">Portuguese alphabet</a>, which later became widely used through Vietnamese institutions during the French colonial period.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292_424-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292-424">[415]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJacques199821_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJacques199821-428">[419]</a></sup> Vietnam's minority groups speak a variety of languages, including: <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A0y_language" title="Tày language">Tày</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muong_language" title="Muong language">Mường</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cham_language" title="Cham language">Cham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khmer_language" title="Khmer language">Khmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nung_language_(Tai)" class="mw-redirect" title="Nung language (Tai)">Nùng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hmong_language" title="Hmong language">Hmong</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Montagnard_(Vietnam)" title="Montagnard (Vietnam)">Montagnard</a> peoples of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> also speak a number of distinct languages, some belonging to the Austroasiatic and others to the <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian</a> language families.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre10_429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre10-429">[420]</a></sup> In recent years, a number of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_sign_languages" title="Vietnamese sign languages">sign languages</a> have developed in the major cities. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A sample of traditional Vietnamese calligraphy" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/220px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/330px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/440px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="760" data-file-height="505"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_calligraphy" title="Vietnamese calligraphy">Vietnamese calligraphy</a> in <i>chữ Quốc ngữ</i>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French language</a>, a legacy of colonial rule, is spoken by many educated Vietnamese as a second language, especially among the older generation and those educated in the former <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>, where it was a principal language in administration, education and commerce. Vietnam remains a full member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">International Organisation of the Francophonie</a> (La Francophonie) and education has revived some interest in the language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrench_Senate1997_430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrench_Senate1997-430">[421]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, and to a lesser extent <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> are known among some northern Vietnamese whose families had ties with the Eastern Bloc during the Cold War.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Van8_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Van8-431">[422]</a></sup> With improved relations with Western countries and recent reforms in Vietnamese administration, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> has been increasingly used as a second language and the study of English is now obligatory in most schools either alongside or in place of French.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Van9_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Van9-432">[423]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade2018_433-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade2018-433">[424]</a></sup> The popularity of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a> has also grown as the country's ties with other East Asian nations have strengthened.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWai-ming20023_434-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWai-ming20023-434">[425]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh_Dinh201663_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh_Dinh201663-435">[426]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirano2016_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirano2016-436">[427]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Culture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Vietnam" title="Culture of Vietnam">Culture of Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg" class="image"><img alt="The Temple of Literature in Hanoi" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/200px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/300px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/400px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Temple of Literature">Temple of Literature</a> in Hanoi
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="The Meridian Gate (Huế)" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg/200px-Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="133" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg/300px-Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg/400px-Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3833" data-file-height="2555"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Imperial_City_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Imperial City of Huế">Imperial City of Huế</a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:%C3%93pera,_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh,_Vietnam,_2013-08-14,_DD_02.JPG" class="image"><img alt="The Municipal Theatre in Ho Chi Minh City" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/200px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="121" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/300px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/400px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5114" data-file-height="3101"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           The <a href="/wiki/Municipal_Theatre,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Municipal Theatre, Ho Chi Minh City">Municipal Theatre</a> (Saigon Opera House) in Ho Chi Minh City
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnam's culture has developed over the centuries from indigenous ancient <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Đông Sơn culture">Đông Sơn culture</a> with wet rice cultivation as its economic base.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigham1984_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigham1984-36">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalò200951_39-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalò200951-39">[33]</a></sup> Some elements of the nation's culture have Chinese origins, drawing on elements of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, Mahāyāna Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a> in its traditional political system and philosophy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETung_Hieu201571_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETung_Hieu201571-437">[428]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-438">[429]</a></sup> Vietnamese society is structured around <i>làng</i> (ancestral villages);<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEndres2001_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEndres2001-439">[430]</a></sup> all Vietnamese mark a <a href="/wiki/Gi%E1%BB%97_T%E1%BB%95_H%C3%B9ng_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" class="mw-redirect" title="Giỗ Tổ Hùng Vương">common ancestral anniversary</a> on the tenth day of the third <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar month</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144-440">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage2012_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage2012-441">[432]</a></sup> The influence of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/Cantonese_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Cantonese culture">Cantonese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hakka_culture" title="Hakka culture">Hakka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hokkien_culture" title="Hokkien culture">Hokkien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainanese</a> cultures is more evident in the north where Buddhism is strongly entwined with popular culture.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142_442-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142-442">[433]</a></sup> Despite this, there are <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatowns</a> in the south, such as in <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%A3_L%E1%BB%9Bn,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Chợ Lớn, Ho Chi Minh City">Chợ Lớn</a>, where many Chinese have <a href="/wiki/Interracial_marriage" title="Interracial marriage">intermarried</a> with Kinh and are indistinguishable among them.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018-443">[434]</a></sup> In the central and southern parts of Vietnam, traces of Champa and <a href="/wiki/Khmer_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Khmer culture">Khmer culture</a> are evidenced through the remains of ruins, artefacts as well within their population as the successor of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Sa_Hu%E1%BB%B3nh_culture" title="Sa Huỳnh culture">Sa Huỳnh culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMomoki199636_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMomoki199636-444">[435]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201184_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201184-445">[436]</a></sup> In recent centuries, Western cultures have become popular among recent generations of Vietnamese.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_438-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-438">[429]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of two girls wearing a traditional Vietnamese white school uniform, the áo dài—both are holding the nón lá, a conical hat" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/170px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/255px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/340px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="601"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Vietnamese traditional white <a href="/wiki/School_uniforms_by_country#Vietnam" title="School uniforms by country">school uniform</a> for girls in the country, the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_d%C3%A0i" title="Áo dài">áo dài</a></i> with the addition of <i><a href="/wiki/Asian_conical_hat" title="Asian conical hat">nón lá</a>,</i> a conical hat.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The traditional focuses of Vietnamese culture are based on humanity (<i>nhân nghĩa</i>) and harmony (<i>hòa</i>) in which family and community values are highly regarded.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142_442-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142-442">[433]</a></sup> Vietnam reveres a number of key cultural symbols,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201296_446-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201296-446">[437]</a></sup> such as the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_dragon" title="Vietnamese dragon">Vietnamese dragon</a> which is derived from <a href="/wiki/Crocodile" title="Crocodile">crocodile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snake" title="Snake">snake</a> imagery; Vietnam's national father, <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Long_Qu%C3%A2n" title="Lạc Long Quân">Lạc Long Quân</a> is depicted as a holy dragon.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144_440-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144-440">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGallop2017_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGallop2017-447">[438]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnamese-American_Association_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnamese-American_Association-448">[439]</a></sup> The <i>lạc</i> is a holy bird representing Vietnam's national mother <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_C%C6%A1" title="Âu Cơ">Âu Cơ</a>. Other prominent images that are also revered are the <a href="/wiki/Turtle" title="Turtle">turtle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">buffalo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChonchirdsin2016_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChonchirdsin2016-449">[440]</a></sup> Many Vietnamese also believe in the <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spiritualism" title="Spiritualism">spiritualism</a> where illness can be brought on by a <a href="/wiki/Curse" title="Curse">curse</a> or <a href="/wiki/Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft">sorcery</a> or caused by non-observance of a religious ethic. Traditional medical practitioners, <a href="/wiki/Amulet" title="Amulet">amulets</a> and other forms of spiritual protection and religious practices may be employed to treat the ill person.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaitemata_District_Health_Board20152_450-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaitemata_District_Health_Board20152-450">[441]</a></sup> In the modern era, the cultural life of Vietnam has been deeply influenced by government-controlled media and cultural programs.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_438-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-438">[429]</a></sup> For many decades, foreign cultural influences, especially those of Western origin, were shunned. But since the recent reformation, Vietnam has seen a greater exposure to neighbouring Southeast Asian, East Asian as well to Western culture and media.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong2012_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong2012-451">[442]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The main Vietnamese formal dress, the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_d%C3%A0i" title="Áo dài">áo dài</a></i> is worn for special occasions such as weddings and religious festivals. White <i>áo dài</i> is the required uniform for girls in many high schools across the country. Other examples of traditional Vietnamese clothing include: the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_t%E1%BB%A9_th%C3%A2n" title="Áo tứ thân">áo tứ thân</a></i>, a four-piece woman's dress; the <i>áo ngũ</i>, a form of the <i>thân</i> in five-piece form, mostly worn in the north of the country; the <i><a href="/wiki/Y%E1%BA%BFm" title="Yếm">yếm</a></i>, a woman's undergarment; the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_b%C3%A0_ba" title="Áo bà ba">áo bà ba</a></i>, rural working "<a href="/wiki/Pyjamas" class="mw-redirect" title="Pyjamas">pyjamas</a>" for men and women; the <i><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_g%E1%BA%A5m" title="Áo gấm">áo gấm</a></i>, a formal brocade tunic for government receptions; and the <i>áo the</i>, a variant of the <i>áo gấm</i> worn by grooms at weddings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewandowski201112_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewandowski201112-452">[443]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoward201690_453-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoward201690-453">[444]</a></sup> Traditional headwear includes the standard conical <i><a href="/wiki/N%C3%B3n_l%C3%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="Nón lá">nón lá</a></i> and the "lampshade-like" <i><a href="/wiki/N%C3%B3n_quai_thao" title="Nón quai thao">nón quai thao</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoward201690_453-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoward201690-453">[444]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChico2013354_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChico2013354-454">[445]</a></sup> In tourism, a number of popular cultural tourist destinations include the former <a href="/wiki/Imperial_City_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Imperial City of Huế">Imperial City of Huế</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> of <a href="/wiki/Phong_Nha-K%E1%BA%BB_B%C3%A0ng_National_Park" title="Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park">Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="Hội An">Hội An</a> and <a href="/wiki/M%E1%BB%B9_S%C6%A1n" title="Mỹ Sơn">Mỹ Sơn</a>, coastal regions such as Nha Trang, the caves of Hạ Long Bay and the <a href="/wiki/Marble_Mountains_(Vietnam)" title="Marble Mountains (Vietnam)">Marble Mountains</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2014_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2014-455">[446]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2017a_456-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2017a-456">[447]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Literature">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_literature" title="Vietnamese literature">Vietnamese literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_poetry" title="Vietnamese poetry">Vietnamese poetry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_fairy_tales" title="Vietnamese fairy tales">Vietnamese fairy tales</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll,_1917_(British_Library).png" class="image"><img alt="A scroll showing a Vietnamese dragon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/250px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/375px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/500px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="503"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll,_1917_(British_Library).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_dragon" title="Vietnamese dragon">Vietnamese dragon</a> on Emperor <a href="/wiki/Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh" title="Khải Định">Khải Định</a>'s <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1917</span> scroll in <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a> collection.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnamese literature has centuries-deep history and the country has a rich tradition of <a href="/wiki/Folk_literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk literature">folk literature</a> based on the typical six–to-eight-verse poetic form called <i>ca dao</i> which usually focuses on village ancestors and heroes.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuong2010_457-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuong2010-457">[448]</a></sup> Written literature has been found dating back to the 10th century <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_dynasty" title="Ngô dynasty">Ngô dynasty</a>, with notable ancient authors including: <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Tr%C3%A3i" title="Nguyễn Trãi">Nguyễn Trãi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_H%C6%B0ng_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1o" title="Trần Hưng Đạo">Trần Hưng Đạo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Du" title="Nguyễn Du">Nguyễn Du</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Chi%E1%BB%83u" title="Nguyễn Đình Chiểu">Nguyễn Đình Chiểu</a>. Some literary genres play an important role in theatrical performance, such as <i>hát nói</i> in <i><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca trù">ca trù</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorton2015_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorton2015-458">[449]</a></sup> Some poetic unions have also been formed in Vietnam, such as the <i>tao đàn</i>. Vietnamese literature has been influenced by Western styles in recent times, with the first literary transformation movement of <i><a href="/wiki/Th%C6%A1_m%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Thơ mới">thơ mới</a></i> emerging in 1932.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELe2008_459-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELe2008-459">[450]</a></sup> Vietnamese folk literature is an intermingling of many forms. It is not only an oral tradition, but a mixing of three media: hidden (only retained in the memory of folk authors), fixed (written), and shown (performed). Folk literature usually exists in many versions, passed down orally, and has unknown authors. <a href="/wiki/Myths" class="mw-redirect" title="Myths">Myths</a> consist of stories about supernatural beings, heroes, creator gods and reflect the viewpoint of ancient people about human life.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo20124_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo20124-460">[451]</a></sup> They consist of creation stories, stories about their origins (<i>Lạc Long Quân</i> and <i>Âu Cơ</i>), <a href="/wiki/Culture_heroes" class="mw-redirect" title="Culture heroes">culture heroes</a> (<a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_Tinh_%E2%80%93_Th%E1%BB%A7y_Tinh" title="Sơn Tinh – Thủy Tinh"><i>Sơn Tinh</i> and <i>Thủy Tinh</i></a>) which are referred to as a mountain and water spirit respectively and many other folklore tales.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018_443-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018-443">[434]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETranLe20175_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETranLe20175-461">[452]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Music">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Vietnam" title="Music of Vietnam">Music of Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Three musicians are performing on a stage." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/220px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="162" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/330px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/440px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1545" data-file-height="1135"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca trù">Ca trù</a> trio performance in northern Vietnam
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traditional Vietnamese music varies between the country's northern and southern regions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_Khè1972_462-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_Khè1972-462">[453]</a></sup> Northern classical music is Vietnam's oldest musical form and is traditionally more formal. The origins of Vietnamese classical music can be traced to the Mongol invasions in the 13th century when the Vietnamese captured a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_opera" title="Chinese opera">Chinese opera</a> troupe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiettinen1992163_463-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiettinen1992163-463">[454]</a></sup> Throughout its history, Vietnam has been the most heavily impacted by the <a href="/wiki/Music_of_China" title="Music of China">Chinese musical tradition</a> along with those of Japan, <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Khê1985_464-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Khê1985-464">[455]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Nh%C3%A3_nh%E1%BA%A1c" title="Nhã nhạc">Nhã nhạc</a></i> is the most popular form of imperial court music, <i><a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A8o" title="Chèo">Chèo</a></i> is a form of generally satirical <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">musical theatre</a>, while <i><a href="/wiki/X%E1%BA%A9m" title="Xẩm">Xẩm</a></i> or <i>hát xẩm</i> (xẩm singing) is a type of Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Quan_h%E1%BB%8D" title="Quan họ">Quan họ</a></i> (alternate singing) is popular in the former <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_B%E1%BA%AFc_Province" title="Hà Bắc Province">Hà Bắc Province</a> (which is now divided into <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Ninh_Province" title="Bắc Ninh Province">Bắc Ninh</a> and <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Giang_Province" title="Bắc Giang Province">Bắc Giang</a> Provinces) and across Vietnam. Another form of music called <i><a href="/wiki/Hat_chau_van" class="mw-redirect" title="Hat chau van">Hát chầu văn</a></i> or <i>hát văn</i> is used to invoke spirits during ceremonies. <i><a href="/wiki/Nh%E1%BA%A1c_d%C3%A2n_t%E1%BB%99c_c%E1%BA%A3i_bi%C3%AAn" title="Nhạc dân tộc cải biên">Nhạc dân tộc cải biên</a></i> is a modern form of Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> which arose in the 1950s, while <i><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca trù">ca trù</a></i> (also known as <i>hát ả đào</i>) is a popular folk music. <i>Hò</i> can be thought of as the southern style of <i>Quan họ</i>. There is a range of traditional instruments, including the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_b%E1%BA%A7u" title="Đàn bầu">đàn bầu</a></i> (a monochord <a href="/wiki/Zither" title="Zither">zither</a>), the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_g%C3%A1o" title="Đàn gáo">đàn gáo</a></i> (a two-stringed <a href="/wiki/Fiddle" title="Fiddle">fiddle</a> with coconut body), and the <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_nguy%E1%BB%87t" title="Đàn nguyệt">đàn nguyệt</a></i> (a two-stringed fretted moon <a href="/wiki/Lute" title="Lute">lute</a>). In recent times, there have been some efforts at mixing Vietnamese traditional music—especially folk music—with modern music to revive and promote national music in the modern context and educate the younger generations about Vietnam's traditional musical instruments and singing styles.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018d_465-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018d-465">[456]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Bolero#Vietnam" title="Bolero">Bolero</a> music has gained popularity in the country since the 1930s, albeit with a different style—a combination of traditional Vietnamese music with Western elements.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuy2016_466-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuy2016-466">[457]</a></sup> However, the modern Vietnamese music industry, known as <a href="/wiki/V-pop" title="V-pop">V-pop</a>, is making its mark in the entertainment field. Many Vietnamese artists have started to collaborate with foreign artists and producers, especially South Korean, to facilitate the entrance of <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a> into the Vietnamese market while also promoting V-pop overseas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChen2018194_467-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChen2018194-467">[458]</a></sup> For example, in 2014, the South Korean seven-member <a href="/wiki/Boy_band" title="Boy band">boy band</a> <a href="/wiki/BTS" title="BTS">BTS</a> (방탄소년단) collaborated with Vietnamese singer <a href="/wiki/North_(band)" title="North (band)">Thanh Bùi</a> on the single called "<a href="/wiki/Dark_%26_Wild#Track_listing" title="Dark &amp;
