Wild">Danger</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChen2018194_467-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChen2018194-467">[458]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Yan_News''2014_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Yan_News''2014-468">[459]</a></sup> In 2018, South Korean artist and idol <a href="/wiki/Park_Ji-yeon" title="Park Ji-yeon">Park Ji-yeon</a> (박지연) collaborated with <a href="https://vi.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soobin_Ho%C3%A0ng_S%C6%A1n" class="extiw" title="vi:Soobin Hoàng Sơn">Soobin Hoàng Sơn</a> on two versions of the title track called "Between Us" (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Đẹp Nhất Là Em</i>; <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>: <span lang="ko">우리사이</span>) to promote the two countries’ partnership in terms of the music industry.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhương2018_469-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhương2018-469">[460]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/V_Live_(website)" class="mw-redirect" title="V Live (website)">V Live</a>, which is a South Korean live video streaming service, also collaborated with RBW Entertainment Vietnam (a subsidiary of <a href="/wiki/RBW_(company)" title="RBW (company)">the Korean entertainment company</a>) to produce Vietnamese-based shows. V Live also launched special monthly mini-concerts called "V Heartbeat Live" to connect V-pop and K-pop idols.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuốc_Hoàng2018_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuốc_Hoàng2018-470">[461]</a></sup> South Korean entertainment company <a href="/wiki/SM_Entertainment" title="SM Entertainment">SM Entertainment</a> signed an agreement with IPP Group to move into the country's market and promote joint business.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESM_Entertainment_Group2018_471-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESM_Entertainment_Group2018-471">[462]</a></sup> The company held its 2018 Global Audition in both Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City in search for new talents among the Vietnamese youth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDam-young2018_472-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDam-young2018-472">[463]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Cuisine">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine" title="Vietnamese cuisine">Vietnamese cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photographs of a phở noodle dish, a chè thái fruit dessert, a chả giò spring roll and a bánh mì sandwich" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/440px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="720"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Some of the notable Vietnamese cuisine, clockwise from top-right: <a href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BB%9F" class="mw-redirect" title="Phở">phở</a> noodle, chè thái fruit dessert, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BA%A3_gi%C3%B2" title="Chả giò">chả giò</a> spring roll and <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_m%C3%AC" title="Bánh mì">bánh mì</a> sandwich.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traditionally, Vietnamese cuisine is based around five fundamental taste "elements" (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i>ngũ vị</i>): spicy (metal), sour (wood), bitter (fire), salty (water) and sweet (earth).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Culture_Information_Network2014_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Culture_Information_Network2014-473">[464]</a></sup> Common ingredients include <a href="/wiki/Fish_sauce" title="Fish sauce">fish sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrimp_paste" title="Shrimp paste">shrimp paste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soy_sauce" title="Soy sauce">soy sauce</a>, rice, fresh herbs, fruits and vegetables. Vietnamese recipes use: <a href="/wiki/Cymbopogon" title="Cymbopogon">lemongrass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_mint" class="mw-redirect" title="Vietnamese mint">Vietnamese mint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eryngium_foetidum" title="Eryngium foetidum">long coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saigon_cinnamon" title="Saigon cinnamon">Saigon cinnamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chilli" class="mw-redirect" title="Bird's eye chilli">bird's eye chilli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lime_(fruit)" title="Lime (fruit)">lime</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basil" title="Basil">basil</a> leaves.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAustralia_Special_Broadcasting_Service2013_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAustralia_Special_Broadcasting_Service2013-474">[465]</a></sup> Traditional Vietnamese cooking is known for its fresh ingredients, minimal use of oil and reliance on herbs and vegetables; it is considered one of the healthiest cuisines worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECorapi2010_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECorapi2010-475">[466]</a></sup> The use of meats such as pork, beef and chicken was relatively limited in the past. Instead freshwater fish, <a href="/wiki/Crustacean" title="Crustacean">crustaceans</a> (particularly <a href="/wiki/Crab" title="Crab">crabs</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Mollusc" class="mw-redirect" title="Mollusc">molluscs</a> became widely used. Fish sauce, soy sauce, prawn sauce and limes are among the main flavouring ingredients. Vietnam has a strong <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a> culture, with 40 popular dishes commonly found throughout the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarkMiller2017_476-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarkMiller2017-476">[467]</a></sup> Many notable Vietnamese dishes such as <i><a href="/wiki/G%E1%BB%8Fi_cu%E1%BB%91n" title="Gỏi cuốn">gỏi cuốn</a></i> (salad roll), <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_cu%E1%BB%91n" title="Bánh cuốn">bánh cuốn</a></i> (rice noodle roll), <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%BAn_ri%C3%AAu" title="Bún riêu">bún riêu</a></i> (rice vermicelli soup) and <i><a href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BB%9F" class="mw-redirect" title="Phở">phở</a></i> noodles originated in the north and were introduced to central and southern Vietnam by northern migrants.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyen2011_477-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyen2011-477">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThakerBarton2012170_478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThakerBarton2012170-478">[469]</a></sup> Local foods in the north are often less spicy than southern dishes, as the colder northern climate limits the production and availability of spices.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2017_479-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2017-479">[470]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Black_pepper" title="Black pepper">Black pepper</a> is frequently used in place of <a href="/wiki/Chilli_pepper" class="mw-redirect" title="Chilli pepper">chillis</a> to produce spicy flavours. Vietnamese drinks in the south also are usually served cold with <a href="/wiki/Ice_cube" title="Ice cube">ice cubes</a>, especially during the annual hot seasons; in contrast, in the north hot drinks are more preferable in a colder climate. Some examples of basic Vietnamese drinks include <i><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_iced_coffee" title="Vietnamese iced coffee">cà phê đá</a></i> (Vietnamese iced coffee), <i><a href="/wiki/Egg_coffee" title="Egg coffee">cà phê trứng</a></i> (egg coffee), <i><a href="/wiki/Chanh_mu%E1%BB%91i" title="Chanh muối">chanh muối</a></i> (salted pickled lime juice), <i><a href="/wiki/C%C6%A1m_r%C6%B0%E1%BB%A3u" title="Cơm rượu">cơm rượu</a></i> (glutinous rice wine), <i><a href="/wiki/N%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_m%C3%ADa" class="mw-redirect" title="Nước mía">nước mía</a></i> (sugarcane juice) and <i><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_lotus_tea" title="Vietnamese lotus tea">trà sen</a></i> (Vietnamese lotus tea).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBatruny2014_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBatruny2014-480">[471]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Media">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Vietnam" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Vietnam">Media of Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg" class="image"><img alt="Shown is the logo of the state broadcaster Vietnam Television." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/220px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="91" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/330px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/440px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="663" data-file-height="273"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Television" title="Vietnam Television">Vietnam Television</a> (VTV), the main <a href="/wiki/State_television" class="mw-redirect" title="State television">state television</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Vietnam's media sector is regulated by the government under the 2004 Law on Publication.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Assembly2004_481-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Assembly2004-481">[472]</a></sup> It is generally perceived that the country media sector is controlled by the government and follows the official communist party line, though some newspapers are relatively outspoken.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEXuan_Dinh2000_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEXuan_Dinh2000-482">[473]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDattaMendizabal2018_483-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDattaMendizabal2018-483">[474]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_Vietnam" title="Voice of Vietnam">Voice of Vietnam</a> (VOV) is the official state-run national radio broadcasting service, broadcasting internationally via shortwave using rented transmitters in other countries and providing broadcasts from its website, while <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Television" title="Vietnam Television">Vietnam Television</a> (VTV) is the national television broadcasting company. Since 1997, Vietnam has regulated public <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">internet</a> access extensively using both legal and technical means. The resulting lockdown is widely referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Vietnam" title="Internet censorship in Vietnam">Bamboo Firewall</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilkey2002_484-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilkey2002-484">[475]</a></sup> The collaborative project <a href="/wiki/OpenNet_Initiative" title="OpenNet Initiative">OpenNet Initiative</a> classifies Vietnam's level of online political censorship to be "pervasive",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOpenNet_Initiative2012_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOpenNet_Initiative2012-485">[476]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> (RWB) considers Vietnam to be one of 15 global "internet enemies".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReporters_Without_Borders_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReporters_Without_Borders-486">[477]</a></sup> Though the government of Vietnam maintains that such censorship is necessary to safeguard the country against obscene or sexually explicit content, many political and religious websites that are deemed to be undermining state authority are also blocked.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBerkman_Klein_Center2006_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerkman_Klein_Center2006-487">[478]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_festivals">Holidays and festivals</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Holidays and festivals">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Vietnam" title="Public holidays in Vietnam">Public holidays in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_traditional_festivals_in_Vietnam" title="List of traditional festivals in Vietnam">List of traditional festivals in Vietnam</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A large round white fabric band decorated with red figures and images for Tết" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/220px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/330px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/440px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Special <a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt" title="Tết">Tết</a> decoration in the country seen during the holiday
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The country has eleven national recognised holidays. These include: <a href="/wiki/New_Year" title="New Year">New Year</a>'s Day on 1 January; Vietnamese New Year (<a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt" title="Tết">Tết</a>) from the last day of the last lunar month to fifth day of the first <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar month</a>; <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B9ng_Kings%27_Festival" title="Hùng Kings' Festival">Hung Kings Commemorations</a> on the 10th day of the third lunar month; <a href="/wiki/Reunification_Day" title="Reunification Day">Reunification Day</a> on 30 April; <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">International Workers' Day</a> on 1 May; and <a href="/wiki/National_Day_(Vietnam)" title="National Day (Vietnam)">National Day Celebration</a> on 2 September.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENational_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam2012_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam2012-488">[479]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETravel201737_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETravel201737-489">[480]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELoan2018_490-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELoan2018-490">[481]</a></sup> During Tết, many Vietnamese from the major cities will return to their villages for family reunions and to pray for dead ancestors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2016b_491-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2016b-491">[482]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrieu_Dan201792_492-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrieu_Dan201792-492">[483]</a></sup> Older people will usually give the young a <i><a href="/wiki/Red_envelope" title="Red envelope">lì xì</a></i> (red envelope) while special holiday food, such as <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_ch%C6%B0ng" title="Bánh chưng">bánh chưng</a></i> (rice cake) in a square shape together with variety of <a href="/wiki/Dried_fruit" title="Dried fruit">dried fruits</a>, are presented in the house for visitors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2018_493-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2018-493">[484]</a></sup> Many other festivals are celebrated throughout the seasons, including the <a href="/wiki/Lantern_Festival" title="Lantern Festival">Lantern Festival</a> (<i>Tết Nguyên Tiêu</i>), <a href="/wiki/Mid-Autumn_Festival" title="Mid-Autumn Festival">Mid-Autumn Festival</a> (<i>Tết Trung Thu</i>) and various temple and nature festivals.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETravel201734_494-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETravel201734-494">[485]</a></sup> In the highlands, <a href="/wiki/Elephant_racing" title="Elephant racing">Elephant Race Festivals</a> are held annually during the <a href="/wiki/Spring_(season)" title="Spring (season)">spring</a>; riders will ride their elephants for about 1.6&nbsp;km (0.99&nbsp;mi) and the winning elephant will be given sugarcane.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEnglar200623_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEnglar200623-495">[486]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Vietnamese_wedding" title="Traditional Vietnamese wedding">Traditional Vietnamese weddings</a> remain widely popular and are often celebrated by <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Vietnamese" title="Overseas Vietnamese">expatriate Vietnamese</a> in Western countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonLee2005217_496-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonLee2005217-496">[487]</a></sup> In Vietnam, wedding dress has been influenced by Western styles, with the wearing of white <a href="/wiki/Wedding_dress" title="Wedding dress">wedding dresses</a> and black <a href="/wiki/Black_tie" title="Black tie">jackets</a>; however, there are also many who still prefer to choose Vietnamese traditional wedding costumes for traditional ceremonies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanh2008_497-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanh2008-497">[488]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Sports">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Vietnam" title="Sport in Vietnam">Sport in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_traditional_games" title="List of Vietnamese traditional games">List of Vietnamese traditional games</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg/220px-Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg/330px-Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg/440px-Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_National_Stadium" title="Mỹ Đình National Stadium">Mỹ Đình National Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Vovinam" title="Vovinam">Vovinam</a>, <i>kim ke</i> and <i>bình định</i> <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial arts</a> are widespread in Vietnam,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreen2001548_498-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen2001548-498">[489]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENghiaLuan2017_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENghiaLuan2017-499">[490]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> is the country's most popular sport.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''FourFourTwo''2017_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''FourFourTwo''2017-500">[491]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_football_team" title="Vietnam national football team">national team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/ASEAN_Football_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="ASEAN Football Championship">ASEAN Football Championship</a> twice in <a href="/wiki/2008_AFF_Championship" title="2008 AFF Championship">2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_AFF_Championship" title="2018 AFF Championship">2018</a> and reached the <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup_knockout_stage#Vietnam_vs_Japan" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup knockout stage">quarter-finals</a> of <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup">2019 AFC Asian Cup</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''China_Daily''2008_501-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''China_Daily''2008-501">[492]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Saigon_Times_Daily''2018_502-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Saigon_Times_Daily''2018-502">[493]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomes2019_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomes2019-503">[494]</a></sup> its junior team of <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_under-23_football_team" title="Vietnam national under-23 football team">under-23</a> became the runners-up of <a href="/wiki/2018_AFC_U-23_Championship" title="2018 AFC U-23 Championship">2018 AFC U-23 Championship</a> and reached fourth place in <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_2018_Asian_Games" title="Football at the 2018 Asian Games">2018 Asian Games</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_under-20_football_team" title="Vietnam national under-20 football team">under-20</a> managed to qualify the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a> for the first time in their football history.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERick2018_504-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERick2018-504">[495]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYanJunLong2018_505-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYanJunLong2018-505">[496]</a></sup> The national football <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Vietnam women's national football team">women's team</a> also traditionally dominates the <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Southeast_Asian_Games#Women's_tournament" title="Football at the Southeast Asian Games">Southeast Asian Games</a>, along with its chief rival, <a href="/wiki/Thailand_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Thailand women's national football team">Thailand</a>. Other Western sports such as <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ping-pong" class="mw-redirect" title="Ping-pong">ping-pong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a> are also widely popular. Vietnam has participated in the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> since <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1952 Summer Olympics">1952</a>, when it competed as the State of Vietnam. After the partition of the country in 1954, only South Vietnam competed in the games, sending athletes to the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1956_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1956 Summer Olympics">1956</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1972_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1972 Summer Olympics">1972</a> Olympics. Since the reunification of Vietnam in 1976, it has competed as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, attending every Summer Olympics from <a href="/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics" title="1988 Summer Olympics">1988</a> onwards. The present Vietnam Olympic Committee was formed in 1976 and recognised by the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) in 1979.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Olympic_Committee2018_506-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Olympic_Committee2018-506">[497]</a></sup> Vietnam has never participated in the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a>. In 2016, Vietnam won their first <a href="/wiki/Gold_medal" title="Gold medal">gold medal</a> at the Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESims2016_507-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESims2016-507">[498]</a></sup> By the 2020s, Vietnam will host the inaugural <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> Vietnam Grand Prix in the city of Hanoi.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFormula_One2018_508-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFormula_One2018-508">[499]</a></sup> Basketball has become an increasingly popular sport in Vietnam, especially in <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soc_Trang" class="mw-redirect" title="Soc Trang">Soc Trang</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">[500]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: See also">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Vietnam-related_articles" title="Index of Vietnam-related articles">Index of Vietnam-related articles</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Vietnam" title="Outline of Vietnam">Outline of Vietnam</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <div class="noprint metadata navbox" role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" style="font-weight:bold;padding:0.4em 2em">
       <ul style="margin:0.1em 0 0">
        <li style="display:inline"><span style="display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap"><span style="margin:0 0.5em"><a href="/wiki/File:Asia_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="image"><img alt="Asia (orthographic projection).svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/21px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="21" height="21" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/32px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="541"></a></span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Asia" title="Portal:Asia">Asia portal</a></span></li>
        <li style="display:inline"><span style="display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap"><span style="margin:0 0.5em"><a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Vietnam.svg" class="image"><img alt="Flag of Vietnam.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/24px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png" decoding="async" width="24" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/36px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Flag_of_Vietnam.svg/48px-Flag_of_Vietnam.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></a></span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Vietnam" title="Portal:Vietnam">Vietnam portal</a></span></li>
       </ul>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Notes">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Constitution of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam states that <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> is the "national language", rather than the "official language"; Vietnamese is the only language used in official documents and legal proceedings <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Also called Kinh people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECommunist_Party_of_Vietnam2004_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECommunist_Party_of_Vietnam2004-3">[2]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Nguyễn Phú Trọng is also <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_the_Central_Military_Commission_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Secretary of the Central Military Commission of the Communist Party of Vietnam">Secretary of the Central Military Commission of the Communist Party of Vietnam</a>. The first priority political position in <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one party</a> <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist state</a>, Vietnam is <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam">General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam</a>, not <a href="/wiki/President_of_Vietnam" title="President of Vietnam">President of Vietnam</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In effect since 1 January 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam2014_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam2014-8">[5]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The South China Sea is referred to in Vietnam as the East Sea (<i lang="vi" title="Vietnamese-language text">Biển Đông</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECham2012_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECham2012-15">[11]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-etymology-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-etymology_22-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-etymology_22-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">At first, <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Gia Long</a> requested the name "Nam Việt", but the <a href="/wiki/Jiaqing_Emperor" title="Jiaqing Emperor">Jiaqing Emperor</a> refused.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200238_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200238-18">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShaofeiGuoqing2016_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShaofeiGuoqing2016-21">[16]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Neither the American government nor Ngô Đình Diệm's State of Vietnam signed anything at the 1954 Geneva Conference. The non-communist Vietnamese delegation objected strenuously to any division of Vietnam; however, the French accepted the Việt Minh proposal<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGravel1971134_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGravel1971134-111">[105]</a></sup> that Vietnam be united by elections under the supervision of "local commissions".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGravel1971119_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGravel1971119-112">[106]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, with the support of <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, countered with the "American Plan",<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGravel1971140_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGravel1971140-113">[107]</a></sup> which provided for <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>-supervised unification elections. The plan, however, was rejected by <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a> and other communist delegations.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKort201796_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKort201796-114">[108]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-area-168"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-area_168-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">List of countries and dependencies by area</a>.</span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-202"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-202">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The national symbol of Vietnam is officially recognised in the country's legal documents, including in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Vietnam" title="Constitution of Vietnam">Constitution</a>, which establishes the national flag, national emblem and national anthem. Although Vietnam is a country with many flowers, there is no document recognising its <a href="/wiki/Floral_emblem" title="Floral emblem">national flower</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a> (ASEAN) countries and all of Vietnam's neighbours have national flowers. The <a href="/wiki/Nelumbo_nucifera" title="Nelumbo nucifera">Lotus</a> has been chosen by <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> as its national flower, but this does not preclude Vietnam making the same choice. Many countries have chosen the same flower as their national flower; for example, the <a href="/wiki/Rose" title="Rose">rose</a> is the national flower of <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> and the United Kingdom.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMạnh_CườngNgọc_Lin2010_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMạnh_CườngNgọc_Lin2010-201">[193]</a></sup></span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Further reading">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Print">Print</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Print">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

        <li>

         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFJapan_Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism" class="citation journal cs1">Japan Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mlit.go.jp/kokudokeikaku/international/spw/general/vietnam/index_e.html">"An Overview of Spatial Policy in Asian and European Countries"</a>. <i>Local Governments and Spatial Planning System</i>. <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism" title="Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism">Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism</a> (Japan).</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Local+Governments+and+Spatial+Planning+System&amp;rft.atitle=An+Overview+of+Spatial+Policy+in+Asian+and+European+Countries&amp;rft.au=Japan+Ministry+of+Land%2C+Infrastructure%2C+Transport+and+Tourism&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mlit.go.jp%2Fkokudokeikaku%2Finternational%2Fspw%2Fgeneral%2Fvietnam%2Findex_e.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: multiple names: authors list (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_multiple_names:_authors_list" title="Category:CS1 maint: multiple names: authors list">link</a>) CS1 maint: ref=harv (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_ref%3Dharv" title="Category:CS1 maint: ref=harv">link</a>)</span></li>

        <li>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="News_and_magazines">News and magazines</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: News and magazines">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Websites">Websites</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: Websites">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1004355016">

       <ul>
        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFTran2018" class="citation web cs1">Tran, Anh Q. Brill.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+Historiography+of+the+Jesuits+in+Vietnam%3A+1615%E2%80%931773+and+1957%E2%80%932007&amp;rft.pub=Brill&amp;rft.date=2018&amp;rft.aulast=Tran&amp;rft.aufirst=Anh+Q.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Freferenceworks.brillonline.com%2Fentries%2Fjesuit-historiography-online%2Fthe-historiography-of-the-jesuits-in-vietnam-16151773-and-19572007-COM_210470&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span></li> 
        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSaganDenny1982" class="citation web cs1">Sagan, Ginetta; Denny, Stephen (1982). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~sdenney/Vietnam-Reeducation-Camps-1982">"Re-education in unliberated Vietnam: Loneliness, Suffering and Death"</a>. <i>The Indochina Newsletter</i>. <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley" title="University of California, Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Indochina+Newsletter&amp;rft.atitle=Re-education+in+unliberated+Vietnam%3A+Loneliness%2C+Suffering+and+Death&amp;rft.date=1982&amp;rft.aulast=Sagan&amp;rft.aufirst=Ginetta&amp;rft.au=Denny%2C+Stephen&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ocf.berkeley.edu%2F~sdenney%2FVietnam-Reeducation-Camps-1982&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: ref=harv (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_ref%3Dharv" title="Category:CS1 maint: ref=harv">link</a>)</span></li> 
        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFNam_DangNielsen2019" class="citation web cs1">Nam Dang, Vu Hoai; Nielsen, Martin (2019). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.pri.org/stories/2019-05-02/we-asked-people-vietnam-why-they-use-rhino-horn-here-s-what-they-said">"We asked people in Vietnam why they use rhino horn.         <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFThi_Anh" class="citation web cs1">Thi Anh, Do. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181010120818/https://www.adpc.net/igo/contents/iPrepare/iprepare-news_id.asp?ipid=223">"Flood in Vietnam"</a>. Asian Disaster Preparedness Center. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.adpc.net/igo/contents/iPrepare/iprepare-news_id.asp?ipid=223">the original</a> on 10 October 2018.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Flood+in+Vietnam&amp;rft.pub=Asian+Disaster+Preparedness+Center&amp;rft.aulast=Thi+Anh&amp;rft.aufirst=Do&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.adpc.net%2Figo%2Fcontents%2FiPrepare%2Fiprepare-news_id.asp%3Fipid%3D223&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: ref=harv (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_ref%3Dharv" title="Category:CS1 maint: ref=harv">link</a>)</span></li> 
        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFUNESCO_Publishing" class="citation web cs1">UNESCO Publishing. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002354/235406e.pdf">"UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. UNESCO.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=UNESCO+Science+Report%3A+towards+2030&amp;rft.pub=UNESCO&amp;rft.au=UNESCO+Publishing&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Funesdoc.unesco.org%2Fimages%2F0023%2F002354%2F235406e.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: ref=harv (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_ref%3Dharv" title="Category:CS1 maint: ref=harv">link</a>)</span></li>

        <li>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFUnited_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs" class="citation web cs1">United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://population.un.org/wpp/DataQuery/">"Data Query"</a>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs" title="United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs">United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Data+Query&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations+Department+of+Economic+and+Social+Affairs&amp;rft.au=United+Nations+Department+of+Economic+and+Social+Affairs&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fpopulation.un.org%2Fwpp%2FDataQuery%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: ref=harv (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_ref%3Dharv" title="Category:CS1 maint: ref=harv">link</a>)</span></li>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Free_content">Free content</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: Free content">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1004355016">
      <div class="refbegin" style=""> 
       <p><a href="/wiki/File:Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg" class="image"><img alt="Definition of Free Cultural Works logo notext.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg/12px-Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="12" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg/18px-Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg/24px-Definition_of_Free_Cultural_Works_logo_notext.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="219" data-file-height="218"></a>&nbsp;This article incorporates text from a <a href="/wiki/Free_content" title="Free content">free content</a> work. . Text taken from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0023/002354/235406e.pdf"><i>UNESCO Science Report: towards 2030</i></a>, 713–714, UNESCO, UNESCO Publishing. <span role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable"><i>To learn how to add <a href="/wiki/Free_license" title="Free license">open license</a> text to Wikipedia articles, please see <a href="/wiki/Help:Adding_open_license_text_to_Wikipedia" title="Help:Adding open license text to Wikipedia">this how-to page</a>. For information on <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reusing_Wikipedia_content" title="Wikipedia:Reusing Wikipedia content">reusing text from Wikipedia</a>, please see <a href="https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:MyLanguage/Terms_of_use" class="extiw" title="m:Special:MyLanguage/Terms of use">the terms of use</a>.</i></span><br> <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/12px-PD-icon.svg.png" decoding="async" width="12" height="12" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/18px-PD-icon.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/62/PD-icon.svg/24px-PD-icon.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="196" data-file-height="196">&nbsp;This article incorporates&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Copyright_status_of_works_by_the_federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Copyright status of works by the federal government of the United States">public domain material</a> from the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">United States Department of State</a> document: 
        <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://2001-2009.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/4130.htm">"(U.S. Relations With Vietnam)"</a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%28U.S.+Relations+With+Vietnam%29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2F2001-2009.state.gov%2Fr%2Fpa%2Fei%2Fbgn%2F4130.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVietnam" class="Z3988"></span> </p>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Government">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <ul>
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://chinhphu.vn/portal/page/portal/English">Portal of the Government of Vietnam</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://cpv.org.vn/">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> – official website (in Vietnamese)</li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://quochoi.vn/en-US/Pages/default.aspx">National Assembly</a> – the Vietnamese legislative body</li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gso.gov.vn/Default_en.aspx?tabid=491">General Statistics Office</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.mofa.gov.vn/en/">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a></li> 
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/world-leaders-1/VM.html">Chief of State and Cabinet Members</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_censorship">Media and censorship</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=52" title="Edit section: Media and censorship">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <ul>
       <li>Robert N. Wilkey. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120719190536/http://www.jcil.org/journal/articles/160.html">"Vietnam's Antitrust Legislation and Subscription to E-ASEAN: An End to the Bamboo Firewall Over Internet Regulation?"</a> <i>The John Marshall Journal of Computer and Information Law</i>. Vol. XX, No. 4. Summer 2002. Retrieved 16 February 2013.</li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism_2">Tourism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Tourism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <ul>
       <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vietnamtourism.gov.vn/english/">Official tourism website</a></li>
      </ul>

                   <li><a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a></li> 
                   <li><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Vietnam</a></li> 
                   <li><a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a></li>
                  </ul> 
                 </div></td>
                <td class="noviewer navbox-image" rowspan="3" style="width:1px;padding:0px 0px 0px 2px;padding: 0 0.5em;">

                  <a href="/wiki/File:Asia_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="image"><img alt="Asia (orthographic projection).svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/100px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="100" height="100" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/150px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/200px-Asia_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="541" data-file-height="541"></a>
                 </div></td>
               </tr>
